data.name: Heijō Palace Site Historical National Park

reviews.text:
It seems a new tourist spot of Nara. Some building are still under construction and it looks like Nara is trying to rebuild the lost palace of Heijo. There are many attractions in the park. 3-4 museums about history of Heijo palace and real excavations. If you are fans of Asian history, you should visit the museum. Almost a copy and record of Chinese tang dynasty. Some pseudo antique buildings like 朱雀门 太极门 are very impressive. There is even a replica ship demo (when Japan sent students to China to study abroad 1300 years ago). The park is full of feeling about history. The only issue which is really bugging is that the park is too big to walk to all attractions. Mission impossible especially in summer. The park should provide some rental bicycles service. Another big problem is that the whole park is cut through by Nara railway track. If you sit in front of Suzaku gate, you will un see the train running across the park almost every 5 minutes.

BTW, there is a small coffee shop named IRACA, close to the tourist center. very yummy ice cream and special drinks & coffee.  Strongly recommend to try.

From the year 710 to 794, Nara was the    capital of Japan and known as Heijo-kyo. The Heijo Palace in Nara   was the Emperor's residence and government offices. All of the original palace us lost and when the capital shifted from Nara, the palace was abandoned and most of the area was used as rice field. The palace has great historical and cultural importance and  included as a Special Historic Site in 1952, and in 1998 as UNESCO  World Heritage Site. We could visit it from outside as entry into the palace is not permitted.

During April 2024 during my japan visit ,I went to see The Heijo Palace in Nara .It  was the Emperor's residence and government offices. All of the original palace was lost and when the capital shifted from Nara, the palace was abandoned and most of the area was used as rice field. The palace has great historical and cultural importance

If you are a foreign visitor to Japan, I suggest skipping this site as there are other, more interesting things to see around Nara. This site has historical significance, but I think you would be better served reading about it instead of visiting it. The grounds are huge but mostly empty. There are a couple of modern reconstructions of buildings, but you can't enter them (and they are located about 1 kilometer back behind the visitor center). There is a museum on-site (referred to as the "Guidance Center") which gives some good information about the Imperial Palace that existed here, though it seems mostly focused towards local school children.

If you do visit, I'd browse the museum and maybe watch the little video about the envoy to China, but don't bother walking back to the reconstructed buildings, as there isn't really anything you can do back there.

I recently had the pleasure of visiting the Heijō Palace Site Historical Park during my trip to Japan, and I must say, it was a truly enlightening experience. Nestled in the heart of Nara, this historical site offers a captivating glimpse into Japan's rich cultural heritage.

The small museum located within the park serves as a perfect complement to the archeological site. Housing a curated collection of artifacts, replicas, and informative exhibits, it offers visitors a comprehensive overview of the palace's history and significance. The interactive displays truly brought the past to life, allowing me to better understand the daily lives of the imperial court and the societal norms that prevailed during that era.

One of the highlights of my visit was witnessing the ongoing excavation work conducted by dedicated archeologists. It's fascinating to witness history being meticulously uncovered and to see firsthand the level of care and expertise that goes into preserving these invaluable remnants. The opportunity to engage with the archeologists and learn about their findings added an extra layer of authenticity and depth to my visit.

What I like about the station is that there is a tourist information where you can have different things like a cafe, information about Nara and purchasing tickets for bus etc. There is also toilet and nursing room.
It's a clean place and the staff are very kind and helpful

Visited here after our visit to Nara Park as they have a prayer space here. The staff were very friendly and quick to assist us. We opted to have one prayer room, not knowing that it's only nice for one person to use at one time 🙊😅

They have some souvenirs for Nara Park on sale as well.
Wonderful moments at Nara , Osaka , Japan
Excellent tourist info office featuring helpful staff, great maps and a Starbucks inside. Clean toilets too.

This place is their prayer room, the prayer room is on the left at entrance door. If you need this prayer room, please ask the staff at baggage store section and they will help you. Please remember that you have to write down your name, from and where in Japan do you stay. You get the privacy but don't forget to tell them if you finish your praying.

We visited today the Heijo palace, and during our visit of this museum (free), one of the guide explained to us all of the history of the palace, it was very interesting (in english) !
At the different spots you can get one or two stamps which are very pretty (different colors and represent each spot). It was not crowed unlike nara park and the ballad around the palace is very nice and soothing 😊 Be prepared to walk a lot as the site of the palace is very big ! Some parts are under construction but you can appreciate all of it anyway.
Staff try to explain each item to me in English. I’m so appreciative that he let me know the new knowledge about this palace. It’s so amazing.
Neat little museum with explanations on what the Heijo excavation site is. Really glad that a fair amount was translated. The exhibitions themselves were well put together. Worth a visit.
The building method which was adopted at that time is introduced. I am looking forward to Heijo-kyo's resurgence.
Peace environment ☺️
Location is along a small lane amongst residential and shops. Entry is free. Very quiet and leisurely place. Require to remove shoes
Interesting traditional house. Some rooms are not well lit - just be very careful about a dangerous step in one of the rooms at the rear - saw lots of people tripping over it, me included.

Free admission to this beautiful grid house. Very glad we stopped by on our way to the train station. They open all the rooms so you get to walk around on tatami and see what each layout looks like. You'll get to experience the sliding doors, staircase with drawers, and see how they were able to conserve the spaces. The attic was nice and their small courtyard was amazing. When we were there, it was raining pretty hard so it felt slightly cold. But I can picture how nice it'll get when it's warmer with the sun. Lots of light sources in the house.

What a nice place! The house is really well kept. When you enter you feel transported to the old times. However, the best part for me was the lady working there, which was super nice to us and made everything possible for us to have a good experience. I can’t say enough how much she made our day!

The house is well-kept and it's very interesting and fun to explore.
I was the only visitor when I came on the weekend and had the house to myself to explore and imagine what living there might have been like. Highly recommend for an authentic experience! (Added bonus is that it is free!)

It’s a leisurely stroll through castle grounds with a beautiful view of Nara City.  The cherry blossoms are not yet blooming but it’s still pretty beautiful here.  There’s a spring festival with lots of yummy food and activities for children.  At night the lanterns are very pretty. Parking is free at the back. There’s an entrance from the back as well through the school path.

A castle ruin away from urban jungle.

A small solemn yet appealing attraction out of the city. Quiet, peaceful but beautifully preserved with stunning view of Nara. The intricate stone walls made by skilled masons was admirable in its own right. Very few visitors around probably due to its hidden location from downtown Osaka. There’s a coffee shop within and the outdoor tables are so relaxing and pet friendly too!

Can be reached via Kintetsu-Kashihara Line and get off at Kintetsu-Koriyama Station west exit. From here use Google map and follow the direction on foot to the site.
Amazing experience. Beautiful place to watch the sakura. There happened to be groups performing dances and it was amazing to watch.

It’s a nice place to visit during ume/plum and sakura/cherry blossom seasons.

Free entrance and parking (Feb 2024)
This was a very cozy walk. Not a lot of tourists were here. The castle was gone but the ruins were also amazing to look at. The view up on top of the ruin was also really cool.

The prison was used until 2017. We can se and feel the real lifestyle there.
In 2024, they will be open as prison hotel.
Sounds very interesting!

A beautiful prison,
Now closed and left to decay,
A new life as a hotel.

The walls, once strong and stern,
Now crumble and fade away,
A new chapter to be born.

The bars, once cold and grim,
Now rust and gather dust,
A new purpose to be found.

A beautiful prison,
Now closed and left behind,
A new life awaits.
Nice

The inside of the prison is temporarily closed, but you can just look at the gate itself and take photos.
If it's around 9am, there will be fewer people and you'll be able to take more photos, but the neighborhood is a residential area, so please be careful about making noise and listening to muffler sounds from cars and motorcycles.

◆First visit in April 2020
I learned about this place on Instagram and wanted to take some photos, so I went there.
Since the hotel is under renovation, I only took photos of the brick gate, but that's enough.
It's a very nice scenery.

I did not stay at the hotel, I just went for the renowned onsen. As a Canadian, who doesn’t have bath houses in my country and I have only been to a few. This is the best onsen I’ve ever been to. I would pick this over my regular bathtub any day. They have so many different baths to choose from, my favorites, were the pot baths outside the milky bath inside and the cold dip. They also have a very wide range of Sauna selection, and my favourite was the medicinal one. you could lie down, and there were headrests. it was just a wonderful experience. Great community not too many people very hygienic, and the front desk was very helpful. I definitely recommend if you’re a foreigner or local. it is also kid friendly as I saw many children, but make sure if you bring your child they’re being very respectful and quiet.
The spacious bath is the best. It is convenient that it is open 24 hours.

A decent modern hot-spring / wellness complex and excellent value for money for the location. It’s not got anything on the famous hot-spring locations but if you need a good bath the bank, that’s open 24hours, it’s worth considering.

My son and I come to this onsen resort many times before the pandemic and this February, we again stayed at the Nara Kenko Land and Plaza Hotel for almost a month. The facilities/onsen and staff are all very genuinely wonderful and helpful. In particular, I'd like to note the Japanese lady in the Front desk who is fluent in English (Yano-san/矢野 さん). Every time we stay there, it is so great to see her because she has always been so extremely kind and goes out of her way to assist us whenever we need help.  We will definitely come back again. Thank you very much again for an enjoyable stay.

It’s one of the best place if you wanna spend your weekend slowly recharging yourself with your partner or family. There have a lots of different kind of ofuro both indoor and outdoor with variety of options with the temperature, size, pressure and your skin type. If you are willing to pay more, they have a lot more options of massage, sauna and stem, swimming pool

This is a fantastic destination for families. It offers a variety of attractions that cater to kids, such as whimsical playgrounds, interactive exhibits, and exciting rides. Adults can also enjoy themselves with more beautiful views and relaxing gardens. The park's diverse activities and vibrant atmosphere make it an enjoyable experience for visitors of all ages.

Really fun and good vibes kind of place! Go here if you’re looking to experience something unique during your stay at Osaka. We went here from Nara park which should just be about an hour away. You do transfer to a cable car station and then travel up 30 minutes to the top of the mountain where the theme park is located. The views are great and the highlight is the cable car cycle that goes all the way to the corner of the mountain which give you a great view of the city. Great for dates and even perfect for small families.
Fun, old amusement park. You can pay per ride if you don't want to buy a day pass. It is fun riding the cable cars up to the park. There is a dog, cat, music and birthday cake designed cars

Got to go here on a nice summer day !

Tram ride up and down to the park was a fantastic experience , cute dog and cat tram full of nostalgia

Bought the full day pass which meant we were free to play the ride any amount of times until the park closes ( or else either you buy each rides fare or buy a ticket with 12 tickets to use on rides ).

As like most tourists that go there we rode on the scenic rides that let you paddle out into the open mountain view of the city, truly breath taking and amazing especially if you are going with your other half .

Other than actual rides there are a few nostalgic areas too like the old school horror houses and lazer beam shooters.
Don’t expect too much of the restaurants , but we had some good curry and pork cutlets with minimal wait times for seats.

I do think best times will be to visit the park near winter when days are shorter because the park closes at 5pm and to see the IG red sunset on rides the sun had to be setting.

Overall its a must visit in a lifetime park in between Osaka and Nara .

Take around 1 hour to get to the park from Namba

To enter the park is free , you only have to pay to get on the rides

I am from Hong Kong.
And l highly recommend the foreigners come here to view the beautiful scenery. It takes around 40 mins to get here from 心齋橋，but it worths. today is 5 July, the weather is not hot , even there is sunny day. In the mountain , the wind blows. The air is flesh. And easy walk in the park. I don't feel very tired even play for few hours. A restaurant as well.

data.name: 奈良わんぱくランド はしゃきっズ

reviews.text:
During our visit to Nara Kenko Land, our family had an incredible time filled with fun and relaxation.

Despite the long trip from Hong Kong, my two and a half years old daughter had an unforgettable experience at this kid's playground. The variety of activities and play areas kept her engaged and entertained throughout our visit, creating lasting memories for our family.

One standout feature of Nara Kenko Land is that adults can enjoy free-flowing drinks while their children are happily occupied with the activities. This provided a great opportunity for parents to relax and unwind while keeping an eye on their little ones.

Overall, our time at Nara Kenko Land was exceptional, and we look forward to visiting again in the future. If you're seeking a fantastic family-friendly destination that offers both fun for kids and relaxation for adults, Nara Kenko Land is highly recommended.

The kids and I had a blast here, the main inflatable is huge and really fun. Soft drink refills are included in the entrance fee.

I saw some negative reviews complaining a little about kids and some parents running around but honestly, I feel sorry for those peoples children, just let your kids be kids and have fun! My kids loved it and so did I.

I would say the large inflatable is only suitable for children over aged 3 or 4. If you take your small kids on their and they get hurt or scared that’s your issue because the bigger kids are having fun and it’s not their responsibility to look out for your children. Use your common sense.

There's a castle, there's a castle!!!
Parents who are not confident in their physical strength should not attempt this. It's almost like climbing a mountain, and all you can do is watch your child disappear before your eyes.
It is a place where you can feel the strength of children's physical strength and the sadness of your own physical strength.

There is a reception and dining space on the first floor.
And the drinks are endless.

Those who used the pool next door can access it directly through the tunnel on the left side of the bathing room.

We recommend children at least 3 years old or older to use this facility.
You can play with the following, but there isn't much to play with.

*Please refer to the photo for details!!
Please visit my YOUTUBE and insta for the best information.
Thank you very much for your support!!!

☆☆☆☆☆☆☆☆☆☆☆☆

YouTuber : fujibear1920
Instagram: fujibear1920

♡♡♡♡♡♡♡♡♡♡♡♡

Perhaps because I went during Golden Week, it was very crowded.

You can see children crying everywhere.
I wish they would make an effort to reduce the number of people, even if it means limiting the number of people or raising the price when it is crowded.

I was a little disappointed that I couldn't enjoy myself to the fullest because I had to wait my turn to play on the swings and play in the sand.

Also, is it the influence of the drink bar?
The entire play equipment is sticky.

I took my 5-year-old and 2-year-old grandchildren and they had a lot of fun❕It costs 1,200 yen for 2 hours (an additional charge of 660 yen per hour), but the 1-day pass costs 1,600 yen, so the 1-day pass is a better deal. is! ️
The parking lot opens at 10am on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, so I went there at 10am, and the parking lot was already about 80% full〰️😱　Wow😅　What time does everyone start coming?❔❔

There's an air conditioner inside so it's comfortable ❕ There are plenty of lockers and unlimited drinks 🎵
It's small, but there's a food court, so it's very nice.

It's a toy that requires a lot of physical effort, and I climbed up with it and went down the slide many times, but it was very difficult to get to the top〰️😱My grandchildren can climb it easily, but it's very difficult for their old bodies. Tough. . . 💦
But I felt like I returned to my childhood after a long time and it was fun~🎶👍️

I thought I would go a little earlier this time 🎵

Highly recommended❕
Best part of the park i have been too. Nice open field surrounded by sakura trees. Not too crowded, good benches, decent amount of deer. If you are coming to nara to hang out definitely come here

The vast ocean of green grass was very calming at 9:00 am in the morning. Then add the many deers that lay around basking in the warm sun it adds flutters in my heart. There are benches around so take a sit and absorb the area and sometimes the deers would even go to you.

Take a panoramic view of this space because its amazing!
Wonderful and super cute with the deers! You can easily pet them, but be careful they are still wild animals
the view is absolutely phenomenal and breathtaking here. just a little too hot in the summer to explore the whole place xD
Excellent park, super cool that the deers live in the city with people. Exciting when the pack of them all come towards you when you start feeding biscuits.

Very fun mall! A hidden gem. You can take a free shuttle which takes you there for free from the JR Nara station. Every floor of this mall has so much personality and beautiful stores. The biggest highlight for me was the goldfish museum at the 4th floor. You can easily spend 3+ hours visiting everything this mall has to offer. Food court is also alright

Mi Nara Mall is a vibrant destination that caters specifically to children, ensuring a delightful experience for young visitors. The Ninja Park within the mall is designed to provide a playful environment, allowing kids to engage in enjoyable activities. From imaginative games to physical play, the Ninja Park is a hub of excitement.

In addition to the Ninja Park, the mall offers a variety of sports activities, contributing to a well-rounded entertainment experience for children of different interests. Whether it's organized sports or more spontaneous play, there's something for everyone.

Beyond the realm of activities, Nara Mall boasts a diverse shopping experience. Families can explore a range of stores, providing not only entertainment but also opportunities for parents to find unique items for their children.

Adding to the charm of the mall is the presence of a train track passing in front of the parking lot. The colorful trains passing by add an extra layer of fascination for the young ones, turning a simple visit to the parking area into an enchanting spectacle.

In essence, Mi Nara Mall goes beyond being a shopping center; it transforms into a comprehensive entertainment destination for families, blending engaging activities, sports, diverse shopping, and even a touch of whimsy with the passing trains, creating lasting memories for both children and their parents.

Mi Nara (ミ・ナーラ) provides a unique and memorable dining experience that fuses Japanese and international culinary influences. Nestled in a contemporary setting, the restaurant's ambiance is both sophisticated and welcoming. The menu showcases a diverse array of dishes, skillfully prepared with high-quality ingredients. From traditional Japanese delicacies to innovative fusion creations, Mi Nara caters to a range of palates. The attentive service adds to the overall positive experience, making it an excellent choice for both casual outings and special occasions. While the pricing might be on the higher side, the culinary excellence and the inviting atmosphere make Mi Nara a standout dining destination.

The Mi-Nara Aquarium Goldfish Museum is located on the 4th floor of a comprehensive facility 700 meters west of Shin-Omiya Station on the Kintetsu Nara Line. Located on National Route 369 directly across from JW Marriott Hotel Nara, next to Nara City Hall, a walk from the Shin-Omiya station might invite some sweat a bit. City bus ride might be helpful. The facility doesn't open until 10:00, and the escalators don't work either. The museum is also well maintained. Well maintained. You can fully enjoy about 2 hours. Dining facilities available. Recommended for families, couples and senior citizens.
There are photo spots inside, but bare in mind that the use of both tripods and monopods is prohibited.
A nice mall, however the access to the parking lot is very confusing.

We've been going here for every trip to Ikoma that I can remember.  The track is on the side of a hill so it presents different challenges than most tracks.  The track is short but has both technical and decent straights for top speeds.  The staff are great to work with and friendly.  We hope to go again on our next visit.
Good day to you ,  can you tell how to get there From Nara Park? i looked for the direction with google and i need to walk around the highway, is there any other way?
Good
The track layout is very good , Slightly faster karts compared to others. Real fun !
Went here this afternoon and the experience was great!! Staff went out of there way to give me a great karting experience. Would highly recommend
Really nice pond with loads of koi
Star rating minus for location abit inconvenience to access via mass transit transport.
One of best starbucks location and ambiance !!! So serene
Impressive facility worthy of any capital city.
great!!

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-2-4 Seyanishi, Sango, Ikoma District, Nara 636-0812, Japan
data.name: Sango Town Water Park

reviews.text: Really fun water park!

I came here during the holidays before summer vacation. Even though the forecast was for rain, I was able to enjoy it even though it rained.
Elementary school students can enjoy the slider if it's not crowded
My younger child in kindergarten was having fun just in the lazy river.

There were noodles in the vending machine, so I probably didn't have to bring that much.

I went on a sunny day during a three-day weekend in July. Perhaps because it was featured on TV and Instagram last year, every parking lot was full even when I went there first thing in the morning. Even when I thought I was finally able to park, it took me 30 minutes to get in due to the long line.
Both the lazy river and the 25m pool were crowded with more people than washing sweet potatoes.
My husband and I were trying to restrain two young children wearing bracelets and floats, but there were so many people that it was dangerous.
There was only one snack shop for lunch, so we waited in line for 30 minutes starting at 11am.
It was like this last year too, so I think the comments on Instagram such as "It's empty!" and "It's a hidden gem!" are all lies. It may be empty on weekdays, but it's tough on weekends.
By the way, the parking lot is full of cars from outside the prefecture, including Osaka, Wakayama, Kyoto, and Mie.
Furthermore, starting this year, prices have increased for non-town residents.

It was my first visit, and I had a lot of fun. Most of the people were pitching tents so it felt a little cramped. It was a weekday at the end of summer vacation.
I think it was a decent number of people. Parking is free and infants are also free. Many of the lifeguards were young and were very kind to me. The free slider was also authentic and we, as adults, wanted to try it too.
There was a long wait so I gave up.
There were many small children and there was a shallow pool where they could play until closing time.
I'll visit you again.
There's also a nostalgic Cup Noodle vending machine, so you won't have to worry about food.
Shaved ice 🍧 Curry takoyaki potato etc. were delicious.

There is an outdoor pool nearby that is empty (maybe depending on the timing) and has a reasonable size, so it's a good place to go with your kids.
There are children's pools with a depth of 0.3m and 0.5m, and the shallowest 0.3m has a fountain with water falling like a waterfall. There was also a 25m pool with a water depth of 0.9m, and a separate flowing pool and slider (single-seater and two-seater). Last time we only played in the children's pool, so this time we wanted to enjoy the lazy river together, but it seems like it was too early for our 1-year-old, so he ran away with a bang (lol)
The facility itself is a little old, but it feels like it's all you need. If the neighboring townspeople could get it a little cheaper, it would be 5 stars.
The season of Cherry Blossoms every year, there are many small shops like a festival, but from 2020 ... very sad..., the Cherry Blossoms bloomed very beautifully this year as well!
Lovely spot to view Sakura

Only me was foreigner for cherry.
Even local residences are not many, a nice place to enjoy cherry .
Nice Park, But Garbage overflowing when busy noone checking on it all day during an event.
Beautiful Nature

I went on 6 April 2024 with my dog and friends
The night and the lantern 🏮 made the experience unique
There is a few Yatai and you want take beautiful picture of the cherry tree during blooming season !
I am so happy I went here.
It was not very crowded so I was relieved

01/04/24

🌸🌸🌸🌸
Bloom around 80-90% and may comming to full in 1-2 day
I visited on April 4, 2024. It’s almost the end of the journey, but the cherry blossoms are still spectacular. It feels like there are more and more cherry blossoms😀

You can enjoy the row of cherry blossom trees that continue along the river. Since the river is not very wide, it is a little-known spot where the cherry blossom trees are densely packed and look very luxurious.

On the way, the road gets a bit tricky near Shin-Omiya, but the line of trees continues for several kilometers. If you have time, we recommend walking from one end to the other. Be sure to also check out the weeping cherry blossoms at Daibutsu Railway Ruins Park on the upstream side!

The road along the river is not very wide, and above all, it is a residential road in a residential area, so when visiting for cherry blossom viewing, you will need to be careful about the time of day and when taking photos.

I went to see the cherry blossoms on the weekend at the end of March.
If you were driving, it would be small and there didn't seem to be any parking nearby.
There is no parking lot for motorcycles, and it is not a pedestrian-only road, so I wonder if I can pass it? While thinking that
I passed.

The cherry blossoms 🌸 are about 70% in bloom and are fun to look at.
It's done.

Is there a toilet too? I do not understand that well. There are no shops or convenience stores nearby.
I thought it would be a good idea to bring drinks as well.

The largest lake within USJ.
There are good views no matter where you look.
I like the view of the lights when it gets a little dark at dusk.

One hour before closing on weekdays This is the night view of the lagoon seen from the boardwalk snack deck on the Joe's side.
The flashing lights are reflected on the surface of the lake, and the harriers run around in it.The red illumination in the background is especially beautiful.When you come to the side at this time, there is no one on the deck and you have a monopoly.Since it is behind the building, you can see people passing by. I had a relaxing and wonderful time.
The tax refund actually has to wait until 14:00. Is something wrong?
Good view, good view.

The appearance is extremely beautiful.
It was so beautiful that I thought it was a little-known attraction in Universal Studios Japan, so I decided to go in. But I can't find a place to line up.
Since I'm shy, I couldn't ask anyone and was wandering around, but the scenery was beautiful so it wasn't a problem.
As expected, when I took the plunge and asked the staff, I was told that it was not an attraction.
I was impressed by this response, and I felt that the reason why the park is a world-class theme park is that it maintains a beautiful appearance even in areas that are not attractions.
I wasn't able to get in, but I wanted to go again.
*I didn't know the waiting time and whether or not there were reservations, so I wrote it in text.

This museum is relatively small and charges a hefty admission fee. Unfortunately, the special exhibition was overcrowded and failed to justify the cost. Visitors may find better value at other national museums in Kyoto and Tokyo. While the museum strictly enforces a no-photography policy, some exhibit signage was unclear. Additionally, staff members are overly vigilant and may reprimand visitors for taking pictures, which can be off-putting. Overall, this attraction may not be the best use of one's time or resources.

Nara National Museum is a treasure trove of Japanese art and history that left me thoroughly impressed. Here's why it deserves a perfect rating:

Rich Collection
The museum boasts an extensive collection of Japanese art, artifacts, and cultural relics that span centuries of history. From ancient sculptures to intricate paintings, each exhibit offers a fascinating glimpse into Japan's rich cultural heritage.

Informative Exhibits
The exhibits at Nara National Museum are thoughtfully curated and informatively presented, providing visitors with valuable insights into Japanese art, religion, and history. Whether you're a novice or a connoisseur, there's something to learn and appreciate in every gallery.

Stunning Architecture
Housed in a striking building designed by renowned architect Katayama Tokuma, the museum itself is a work of art. The modern architecture seamlessly blends with the surrounding natural landscape, creating a harmonious and visually stunning environment for visitors to explore.

Tranquil Setting
Situated in Nara Park, the museum enjoys a tranquil setting amidst lush greenery and scenic landscapes. The peaceful surroundings enhance the museum-going experience, allowing visitors to immerse themselves fully in the beauty and serenity of their surroundings.

Educational Programs
In addition to its permanent exhibits, Nara National Museum offers a variety of educational programs, workshops, and guided tours for visitors of all ages. These programs provide valuable opportunities for hands-on learning and cultural exchange, enriching the overall museum experience.

Accessibility
Located in the heart of Nara city, the museum is easily accessible by public transportation, making it a convenient destination for both locals and tourists. Its central location also allows visitors to explore other nearby attractions, such as Todai-ji Temple and Kasuga Taisha Shrine.

Overall Impression
In summary, Nara National Museum is a cultural gem that offers a comprehensive and immersive experience for anyone interested in Japanese art and history. With its rich collection, informative exhibits, stunning architecture, tranquil setting, educational programs, and accessibility, the museum truly deserves a perfect rating. Highly recommended for art enthusiasts, history buffs, and curious travelers alike.

It is close today Dec 30 2023, nothing to see much around inside the museum. Long holiday in Japan has started Dec 28 - Jan 3.

It would be nice to come here on Cherry/ Spring season.

Claimed to be one of only 4 national museums in Japan, this museum has permanent collections of Buddhism statue from Nara periodz around the 6th century.  It was amazing to see how the artefacts are preserved and studied.

This was one of my favorite museums I've been to in Japan. Great exhibits. They have some amazing pieces of art and history. I would recommend it to anyone who is already in the park for the deer to get a glimpse at Japan's long history.

A day trip is good enough to explore this wonderful deer park with kids. There's a lot of tourist nowadays, but u still can wander deep into the park where there's not much people and u can sit down, look at the different scenery and feed the deer at the same time.

I absolutely love the bowing deer of Nara! The sika deer here are the cutest and most friendly deer I’ve ever met with no fear of humans at all. In fact they will follow you around for biscuits and bow down to you for food. I got nipped a few times and suggest hiding any food you have on you to prevent this. You can buy crackers for the deer at one of the local vendors. Cost is 200 yen for 10 snacks. We spent about 2 hours here total just petting, feeding and bowing down to the deer for fun. Amazing adorable animals. The fawns were the cutest. Huge tourist attraction so be prepared for crowds. It is free to enter the park. About a 20 minute walk from Nara station to the inner park.

I wasn’t expecting the deer to be so aggressive near the first food station where you can buy deer biscuits. I recommend bypassing that first initial area, there are a dozen spots similar to it and you can walk further into the park and have more engaging interactions with the deer. It was really hot out so we stopped in the shade several times and fed the deer peacefully with our kids.

Beautiful park to visit! If you explore further than the start you’ll see so much more than just the initial park. There’s a Mt further up which boast incredible views on a clear day!

The deer are pretty cheeky but don’t scream and run about the place and you’ll be fine.

Most shops sell the food for 200 yen, hide it if you want to feed the deer further in the park as the ones by the shops will swarm you. Less crowded the further in you go! Be polite and bow and the deer will do the same!

Over all, a pretty beautiful park with some amazing temples / buildings surrounding the area. You can either visit Nara in 1 hour and be done or 5 hours. It depends on what you want to do! Will be very busy even on a rainy day, so be prepared. 10 minute walk from the train station.

Visiting Nara Park was an unforgettable experience! The park is famous for its friendly deer that roam freely and are accustomed to interacting with visitors. One of the highlights was buying special deer crackers, which you can feed to the deer. It's a charming tradition to bow to the deer before feeding them, and they often bow back – such a delightful interaction!

The park itself is beautifully maintained with lush greenery and stunning landscapes. The temples and shrines within the park are in excellent condition, showcasing the rich cultural heritage of the area. Each structure is a marvel, offering a peaceful retreat from the hustle and bustle of everyday life.

I highly recommend a visit to Nara Park to anyone traveling to Japan. It’s a unique blend of nature, culture, and history that you won’t find anywhere else. Can't wait to go back!

I love the place.
The staff are so kind and accommodating.
I enjoyed the origami making.
It's convenient that they have a currency changer machine in the building.
They provide hygiene kits, towels, yukata.
Great place to tryout Kimono, calligraphy, art of Origami and other cultural experiences. Guided by Mr Jay who is fun and informative. Drop by when visiting Nara.

We only went there to do some activities and it was really amazing! Definitely a must do for everyone visiting Nara. Jay was great he explained a lot about history of Nara and pointed us to some great attractions. We even saw a Buddhist purifying ritual thanks to Jay and his recommendations. His colleague wrote are names in kanji. It’s so beautiful. After that we even tried some kimonos and did some origami. Thank you so much Jay and everyone at Nara visitor center! What an amazing day. And it was all for free!

Lovely NARA visitor centre, very helpful staff and we felt very welcomed.
They allow use of wash room with free wifi and there is also NARA SAKE tasting without charge.

Amazing place to come and experience an authentic, cute and few hours of Japanese culture in this place and an amazing and worthwhile place to Stay for a few nights as one explores nara. Not super convenient in terms of bus services or being really near the station but with a 10 min walk or short 5 min drive, one can reach here and be welcomed by warm smiles and a welcoming atmosphere by the staff here. Many of them can speak either Chinese or English which helps so so much! And yes, it's understandable. Not just the basic basic English kind.

Definitely come and check this place out, buy some of their stuff, check out the guided tours they have available and come stay here for a few nights. You can even cook in the kitchen if needed and relax for a while after a day of exploring! Learn to do some calligraphy, have a tea ceremony and wear/ take some pictures in kimonos/yutakas. Service is excellent. Prices are affordable. A few mins walk to a variety of food places and a nearby Starbucks. Plus receive many gifts while here. They do not serve breakfast here however. And if you want something more, check with the front desk! There is also a bath and washing machine available to use here. Pretty awesome really.

I took the assisted electric bicycle tour through Nara during the Golden week of 2024. Remi was quite knowledgeable about the history behind the spots we visited during our tour, he is friendly and patient. I will highly recommend this tour if you want to know the context behind the historic background around Nara Park, at the same time riding the bicycle is a relaxing experience and keeps you active. Thanks .

The version of Nara tour I went on with this cycling tour guide was the "Heart of Nature" Nara tour, which is a relatively new tour they offer, as I understand it. This was early April, which meant cherry blossoms were on the trees, keep in mind that this is not true at other times of year...

They advise you to get there "early" but I got to the site 40 minutes early and ended up waiting alone for much of that, so take "early" to mean "a few minutes early", (a bus-ride is required, so I had limited options for when I could arrive, and erred on the side of caution, unnecessarily, as it turns out). Currently the tour starts in a residential area, gotten to by a fairly short bus ride from Nara train station, but that may change as the tour owner has his eyes on other more central locations.

I'm a 49 year old, out-of-shape asthma sufferer, so I was a little trepidatious, but the uphill parts of the tour are at the beginning, thankfully, and were not too bad. Most were very gentle upward slopes that were no problem at all. Maybe 3, 4 times, I needed to get off my bicycle and walk a few minutes on a slightly steeper slope, along with a couple other folks who wanted to take a breather. The rest of the group waited patiently for us all, and the guide came partway back down the slope to give us assistance if we needed it, mainly moral support and the assurance that he wouldn't leave us behind.

The first part of the tour took us through/around one of Nara's larger shrine complexes, and to a shop which in the past, made katana for samurai, and still does make katana, but whose main product now is beautiful and exceptionally sharp knives using multi-folded steel. Then it was on, up to the highest of 3 crests on Wakakusayama, a small(ish) mountain which overlooks the entire city, and is clear of trees so that you can see for miles (or kilometers ;) ) We had a quick lunch (must bring your own food and drink. Don't forget to hydrate!!) at the top, and then a nice cycle, mostly downward, to an out-of-the-way waterfall, which was picturesque and cool in both senses of the word. Next we went to see the ruins of a small, old temple, but having been burned down (if my memory is correct) there was not really much to see there other than the foundation stones and a small Japanese style storage building. However this was on the way to our last point of interest, Japanese jizo (monk) carvings, protected from damage by an enclosure that made it impossible to get too close, but still a nice surprise out in an area away from the main crowd of people who come to Nara.

All in all, a pleasant day of exercise, seeing Nara's nature and some history, and of course, the deer :) . The guide told us what he could of the area, but it was more about getting away and seeing pretty sights without being crushed by a crowd, than about learning history, so I had no expectations on that front. He was friendly and courteous, and was careful to keep everyone together and safe. Helmets and UV cutting sunglasses are offered for those who wish to use them, and bicycles were chosen according to height and leg length, and were easily adjustable. He made sure we were each comfortable on the bikes, exchanging them with a different bike if we weren't, and giving us some time at the start to get used to them.

I would gladly go again, or on one of their other tours of Nara that have a different focus. They offer a Nara craft beer tour as well, (no cycling for that one!) ;)

What a blast! My partner and I did the Nara Highlights Bike Tour and found that it was the perfect way to explore Nara. Like most cities in Japan, there is simply too much to see in a single trip.
However, this agency has clearly put great effort into curating the perfect experience that gives you ample time to explore the main landmarks of the city efficiently while also showing you some incredible places you are not likely to find on your own!

Remi was our tour guide for the experience and was perfect: funny, knowledgeable, and an excellent photographer! He has spent over a decade cultivating relationships in the area to truly separate this experience from the rest--and it shows!

I am reluctant to go into specifics about the tour because I don't want to spoil any of the memorable moments you will experience. However, I am confident you won't regret your time on this tour. It is a must do!

My family and I did a private e-byke tour with these guides and it was a fantastic experience. It was fun, well prepared and I'd say it is the best way to visit Nara, specially during warm weather.
The final part of the trip, having lunch together in a Izakaya was also great and a good way to learn about food and about japanese culture in general. 100% Recommended!

A B2B review. We recruited a Multi-lingual Tour Guide from Japan Tour Adventure to assist with a Corporate Tour Event in Osaka. We were really impressed with the high levels of professionalism and client care that Remi (the tour guide) showed our guests. We received a lot of great feedback from his group and would wholeheartedly recommend Japan Tour Adventure for anyone looking for a tour in Nara.

This temple is very old and very historical. The hundreds (maybe thousands) of lanterns inside were really interesting and unique. There was a lot to see in the temple and it was definitely worth the price of admission.

But as nice as the temple itself was, my favorite part was the walk to the temple. The dark winding paths through the forest, flanked by stone lanterns (as well as some hungry and curious deer) were so cool. I could walk around that area for days and it would still be enjoyable. Probably my favorite thing I did/saw in Nara Park.
A beautiful historic shrine with an atmospheric walk leading up. There is also an area behind the shrine to explore. About a 10-15 minute walk from Todai-ji's main temple.

Worth a visit when in Nara. Peaceful and stunning at the same time - provided one visits at certain time of the year and day to avoid hordes of tourists. Be careful not to walk on freshly raked fine pebbles when visiting early in the morning!

Thousand of "Lantern Shrine".  Full of stone and wooden lanternes dueing the path to shrine and many more metals  lanterns inside. Not much ppl inside thou...  An amazing surprise is waiting for you: A dark room with full of lightened lanterns (guess this is the only ticket worth). Mesmerizing...
It was breathtakingly beautiful! We went there too early, so the main shrine was still closed. However, we just felt the most  purifying atmosphere with the holistic deer. Amazing!!

data.formatted_address: South Korea, Seoul, Yeongdeungpo District, Gukhoe-daero, 632 유윈시티 15층
data.name: NARA SPACE Seoul R&D Center

reviews.text: There is a clean booth so you can breathe through your nose without worrying about fine dust. The owner gets very angry because the toilet paper rolls in the bathroom sometimes disappear. There are various convenience facilities on the first floor, and the accommodation on the second floor is equipped with sofas so visitors can relax. (Sometimes when I visit, someone who seems to be a regular is occupying the sofa during the early morning hours, making it difficult to use.) I heard that a new car theme was added, so I used it today for the first time in a long time. I also have a doctor to visit.

Located in the heart of Nara, this serene garden oasis offers a tranquil escape from the city's bustle. The garden features three distinct styles, providing a diverse and enriching experience for visitors. One of its greatest advantages is its peaceful atmosphere, free from the crowds of deer that often populate Nara's public spaces. Moreover, admission is free, making it an accessible and relaxing destination for all. Whether seeking a moment of contemplation or a stroll through nature's beauty, this garden is a must-visit destination in Nara. If you’re a fan of moss this is the place to be!

This charming former private residence, now a city-owned property, offers a delightful house and extensive garden free of charge to the public, as per the owner's wishes. Upon entering, visitors can ascend to an elevated gazebo for a picturesque view of the house and a portion of the garden.

Delightful house/garden that used to be a private residence (which runs alongside Isuien, so I recommend visiting both). Hard to  imagine actually owning such a place! The owner donated it to the city, and possibly specified that he wanted admission to remain free. The garden is beautiful, extensive, and well worth a visit. Just after entering, you can walk up to an elevated "gazebo" which provides a nice view of the house and (part of) the garden.

Surprisingly bigger than I thought, it has 3 gardens. Free entrance, it’s hard to navigate from the Main Street it doesn’t have an obvious entrance, there’s another garden next door with entrance fees, makes sure you go through the right gate into this park. Worth detouring even during winter as they still have a lot of greenery l, expect 15min to explore the area.

Beautiful and lush green garden. 🥹🌱Visited in early june.

The admission is free and it’s located close to nara park! Well worth the small detour.

This temple is a hidden gem of the Nara complex and you should definitely go there. There was almost noone compared to the crowds at the main temple. Such a nice contrast! You can get the beautiful view on Kyoto, watch Buddhists praying in the temple and plying the instruments, as well as huge bamboos used as a water drainage system on the floor. There is a very peaceful vibe going around ans you can have the walk back in the small streets listening to the water.

This less visited part of the temple is the most beautiful one if you can make it up the stairs. It is also free of charge and you get great views over the rest of the temple complex and surround Nara city.
A little walk from the main temple, but absolutely worth the walk. Gives a great view over the temple grounds, and also has a unique goshuin to collect.

It’s a smaller temple with views of the city. It lacks the charm of some of the other temples, but it’s a perfect option to go later in the day, after visiting the other 2 temples and enjoying the deers, because most people ignore it. I would definitely make a stop here.

I really like view from here and atmosphere.

The main stream of Todaiji Temple was noisy with hordes of deer and people, but this place is on higher ground, with fewer people and a more relaxed atmosphere where you can feel the wabi sabi.
The main hall of Todaiji Temple and Nara Park are certainly touristy, but I preferred this place.

The temple, one of Japan’s oldest and most significant, is renowned for its beautiful architecture and historical importance. The main hall and the east and west pagodas are impressive, each showcasing intricate designs and craftsmanship. The serene atmosphere of the temple grounds, coupled with the lush greenery, creates a peaceful and reflective environment.

Seem most temple in Japan is nice ..This temple is too... The left side pagoda has these bronze relief scenes inside of Buddha that are incredible (no photos allowed). It’s a rather large complex with much to view, but seems like U could cover it in 1/2hours...
The Pagoda is gorgeous - content is eeally impressive - truly National Treasures and bravo to the Japanese preserving and restoring all these National Treasures

This temple was amazing! The left side pagoda has these bronze relief scenes inside of Buddha that are incredible (no photos allowed). The Buddhas here are absolutely beautiful. It’s a rather large complex with much to view, it’s worth the higher package price of ¥1,700.

Beautiful place and phenomenal construction. The temple is big, but can be covered in an hour or two. We took bus from nara station to go there and it was quite comfortable. Went there early morning in off season, so there was no rush.
Nice Cafe with some selection of foods. Service was slow but the food was delicious. Louder environment overall and other little stores and such in the same area.
Large space with lots of food options, and nice, clean washrooms.  We ordered some matcha treats, and would definitely stop here again next time we're in Nara.

Table-service restaurant with an outside window for takeout. Pasta, pizza, and some cake and ice cream choices. Very convenient to/from the station and and the nearby temples. Set lunch around 1000 yen. Pleasant dining area, good service, about a 10-minute wait for the food.

It is more than tourist center they have good food and excellent service. I came here during my stay at nara. It was freezing and while most restaurants are not taking walk-in, I entered this restaurant and the food was special and good and service was friendly
Highly recommend to all people not only tourists
There was no staff in the counter and I had to turn on the tablet for assistance.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒630-8361 Nara, Ikenochō, 3, 猿沢イン ３F
data.name: Nara Prefecture Visitors Bureau

reviews.text: A really welcoming experience here. Very very friendly and super helpful staff! They also have wifi, free activities including origami, calligraphy, cosplay. Offering g maps and advice and will tailor what they suggest to your time and interests and the weather. SO thoughtful and highly recommend to anyone visiting nara!!

A great service! One of the few wonderful experiences (when it comes to customer service) that I had in Japan (country that unfortunately I don’t find very hospitable) in one month time. The all team was just perfect! Thank you! Great job!

Move in June 2024! It costs about 9,000 yen for a three-person room in a side room on the fourth floor. The hotel's booking customer service can speak Chinese, as can the staff at check-in. The overall contact process was very smooth. The view will be slightly obscured by trees. The six tatami mats are larger than expected, the room also has a refrigerator, and there is a small kitchen on each floor for use! Some staff can speak Chinese and introduced Nara's walking routes. They were very friendly~~ There is a social hall on the first floor. There is a lot of travel information, seals, and stickers for reference. Even if you don't stay, you can come and take a look! You can buy deer cakes at the supermarket below (although the hotel is only open until 7:00, the hotel is not far from other supermarkets!) The scenery outside the hotel is great, and it is super pleasant to take a leisurely walk! There are many shops in the small alley next to it that you can browse! It takes about 10 minutes to walk from the station!

reviews.author_name: 工業工程與管理系歐獻仁
reviews.text: Checked in on June 21, 2013. The service staff are very enthusiastic, especially the big brother in the center who speaks Chinese fluently. I look forward to visiting again.

It's cool so I'm grateful for the hot days.
There is a convenience store, Daily Yamazaki, on the first floor.
The staffers are rude. I went camping with children, but staffers gave us a knife without a cover. It is dangerous.
Worth to visit and stay.

Last time I came here, it was a full-fledged athletic event that was free, and I thought it was pretty old and scary for kids and adults alike, but when I came this time, I was surprised to see that the scars that had been injured last time were newly healed. The price is cheap and I would like to come and stay there sometime. The toilets were also clean.

I experienced athletics.

All the staff members were kind and very polite when giving directions.
It is free for athletic use only, but you must register before entering the mountain.

20 pieces of old-fashioned athletics with a rather wild structure, rather than the currently popular athletics with strict compliance.
They are scattered along mountain roads.
There are also a few places where I think if I fall, I won't just get a scratch.

Nowadays, athletic sports with helmets and harnesses are mainstream, but I was struck by how amazing the physical abilities of children in the past were. (Personal impression)

The child, who is almost 4 years old, was trying his best to use the play equipment to the best of his abilities.
I was able to see the cool things about my dad climbing high places, and he looked happy.
It felt like our strength was being tested in the great outdoors. This is athletic.

There's a snake. There are various insects.
The route is mostly shaded by trees and stays cool even in summer, so long sleeves and long pants are recommended for girls.

The toilets in the administration building are always sparkling clean!

I'll come visit you again ^ ^

This is a must-visit spot in Nara in my opinion, especially if the weather is good. Remember to come in before 5pm and wait for the sunset, you will not regret... Easy to be one of my top 5 sunset scenes in my life.

Used Kasugayama trail from Kasugataisha Honden. Was supposed to go down the other trail but it was so hot, couldn’t see a shade. I hope foreign tourists dont hurt the deer.

Other than that, view was spectacular! 30-40min climb up on pebbled road.

Worth to walk trail, which begins right after Nara park. It ends up in a  hill (Wakakusayama) with spectacular view. Also, many deers present. There is another branch, leading to a waterfall but it's a long walk and you better not try it if you have a family. Walking the Nara park, up the hill and then down again, is already a small challenge.

It was a great experience. The weather was good so we were able to chill and just enjoy the view.

The deers might be pushy/aggressive you if you have/smell like the Deer biscuits (Shika Senbei).

Be aware of deer droppings and items rolling down the hill.

One of the best spots to visit in the Nara area, not only is it a short climb up the hill, it is also a really good view of the city. The best part is, there are deers up the hill which add to the whole experience of the place! Truly not to be missed.

data.formatted_address: 888-1 Fushiogami, Yamazoe, Yamabe District, Nara 630-2225, Japan
data.name: Forest Park Konoyama

reviews.text: Actually it is a nice park to stop by, but if there is no event or other things, the place is quiet, not very interesting. But I recommend for mountain sightseeing.

Very good view
The 360-degree view is perfect for hiking, and there are no people around so you can be alone.

A must-see for those who love touring giant rocks

It's amazing that it's so complete and can be used for free. There were lots of lambs. I thought sheep were wonderful animals. Nabekura Valley was amazing! I've never seen a sight like this before. It was a strange sight. Moreover, the scale is large. It was interesting.
They are closed on Wednesdays, but today they were closed on Thursday as well, so it was boring. However, I was able to see sheep and see Nabekura Gorge. I thought I could get to the top from the road in front of me, but it wasn't a good road, so I decided against it. We passed each other on the way home, but it was a local person, and it was just a big space, so we were saved. It was a scary drive there. I also want to go when it's lit up.

The surrounding area is truly rich in nature and the scenery is outstanding! The road to the top of the mountain is easy to walk, so it takes some time, but if you make the effort to climb the mountain, the view from the observation deck is amazing 😄 It is famous for its azaleas, so I would like to go there again at that time of year. I think so. It's great that the tea fields are beautiful now 😄 The sheep at the farm are also charming and cute 😊 We had a meal at Eizanbeni. It was nice to be able to eat while looking at the view.

There are also three hiking trails, so you can enjoy a variety of things.
A 360-degree panoramic view spreads out from the top of the mountain, and it is said that you can see a variety of scenery depending on the season.
There are many sheep at Meemee Farm (Makiba).
There is also the Nabekura Gorge, where black rocks of various sizes extend for an average width of 25 meters and a length of about 650 meters.
The parking lot is 300 yen (cooperation fee), and you can enter the park for free.

data.formatted_address: 788 Toyoura, Asuka, Takaichi District, Nara 634-0107, Japan
data.name: Amakashi-no-Oka Observatory

reviews.text: Easy hike up. Very nice view
Nice place to rest. It'll give you a nice view of Asuka.
Offers a nice view over the more famous spots in Asuka, while the more distant mountains between Nara and Osaka are also in clear view. Suitable for rests while you go hiking.
A perfect view from Asuka. The cherry blossoms on the top of the mountain are perfectly located. Standing under them looking at Nara prefecture is unique and simply remarkable.
Very nice to get a panoramic view of Asuka

Beautiful park, the access is difficult 😞
Steep climb by car 🚗
But it is a great park once there.
Near by (1km away) you can find a great bamboo forest too.
Don’t forget the mosquitos repellent if you go there
It's so calm and peaceful everytime I visit this place when I return to Japan once yearly.
Very nice place that you can enjoy a calm moment and scenery view

It's been a while since I visited.
You have to go through a narrow path. There is also a police dog training facility nearby. If you climb the small hill, you can get a panoramic view of Ikoma's cityscape.
You can also walk various courses such as Tomyoji Temple.

When I was in elementary school, I went there with my friend's bicycle (number 3).

As usual, it feels nothing but natural.

There are apparently three routes that are mainly taken by car.
From Ikoma, from Yada in Koriyama, from Maruyama.
I went there from Maruyama and was still able to pass through. However, if there is an oncoming car, it will get jammed. Also, it is best not to go there unless you are very confident in driving.
Sharp curves, poor visibility.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒630-8012 Nara, Nijōōjiminami, 1-chōme−3−1 1 ミ・ナーラ 2F
data.name: ニンジャ☆パーク奈良店

reviews.text: I visited Ninja Park for the first time because my child was having trouble practicing vaulting and horizontal bars at nursery school. The staff was very kind and quickly determined where the problem was and gave kind advice. When I was playing on my favorite trampoline, he taught me simple tricks, and when I was able to do them, I was overjoyed and just kept playing on the trampoline! The quality seems to be completely different from the trampolines at other playgrounds, and I want to go there again! I was begged. I thought the price was high, but I felt it was reasonable or even cheap!

I became a monthly member this month.
In elementary school, I was so scared of jumping the box that I couldn't jump, so I was looking for a place where I could practice. I actually wanted to join a gymnastics club, but I couldn't get used to the atmosphere and gave up. At Ninja Park, you can have fun while playing, so your child's motivation will increase and they will be able to try various things without fear! The staff gave me very kind advice, so I am now able to fly up to 6 steps. I've grown a lot in this short period of time. I am very satisfied because I can see my child's growth up close.

I registered as a member for the first time today!
My older child was tired of the indoor playgrounds that are mostly for small children, but since it was cold outside, my parents searched for something indoors and ended up at Ninja Park.

The staff was very kind and taught me some trampoline skills, and the kids loved it and wanted to meet that guy again!

If you stay for 2 to 3 hours at another well-equipped facility, it will cost 3 to 4000 yen, but I thought that 8000 yen per month for a parent and child was cheap. Moreover, it seems that you can even take lessons. Next time I will also participate in the lesson ^ ^

I try my best on the trampoline to lose weight. lol I wish I could lose weight...

The whole thing is dangerous. not safe
A small child wanders around even when jumping on a vaulting box.
I was scared because I thought that if there were small children at the landing point, they would be seriously injured.
I think I need space just for the vaulting box.
The whole place has a mess of equipment, it's too small, it's too low, and it's scary.

I guess it's too expensive. Staff work two-on-two with specific children. There's no one at the cash register. Is it because today is winter vacation? Early year-end and New Year fees? The price was for Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays. I was surprised that there was no specific explanation... The kids were having fun though. I was surprised that the price was the same for adults. The response was surprising. Risk management is poor.

My husband and I had stayed at the JW Marriott Hotel Nara in February 2024 but I just got time to share my experience now in July. (Delayed review.lol)

We had an absolutely delightful time! I would give our experience a solid 10 out of 10.

From the moment we arrived, the staff warmly greeted us and assisted with our luggage and check-in seamlessly and enthusiastically.

We dined at Silk Road Dining, ordered room service, and enjoyed spa treatments for both of us. Every aspect of our stay was excellent, and we couldn't be more pleased. The service, in particular, was spectacular!

Although the staff may not be fluent in English, their dedication and service mind far surpassed any language barriers.

Additionally, we loved the convenience of the free mini bus to downtown – it made getting around so easy and stress-free.

Thank you, JW Marriott Nara, for an unforgettable stay. We highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting the area!

I wish we could give this hotel 6 stars. From the very moment we walked in the door the service at this hotel was unbelievably amazing. Very kid friendly yet extremely nice and sophisticated. The breakfast was delicious, the room was very comfortable, the pool was great. They even had kids pajamas, robes, and slippers which made our kids week. We seriously did not want to leave. A sincere thank you to max for his hospitality and assistance. We can’t wait to come back.

We stayed at Marriot Nara during our trip to the region and we couldn't be happier with our experience.

our room was huge with a living room area and a huge bathroom.

the breakfast is served in the ground floor and has a great balance of local Nd international dishes.

the staff is always available and ready to help.

if you have access the the lounge area, you have complimentary food and drinks daily including alcohol and snacks during dinner time.

the swimming pool is lovely and a great way to relax after a long day exploring the region.

Staying at the hotel totally made our stay and we look forward to be back next summer!

Excellent stay with superb staff/service. All staff took extra steps to ensure our stay was seamless. I would only complain about the dinner at the lobby restaurant. The pace of food service was completely off, and the price was high considering the quality of product

Great hotel for a Nara stop.  Rooms are a good size and nice,  tranquil decor.  Feels great sinking into the bed!

Good range of facilities.  Recommend using the hotel bikes for a ride around Nara, lot easier than walking from temple to temple.

Had access to the Club which has a good range of snacks and drinks.  There is a Tsutaya books just behind the hotel.

Location wise it's not that central but there is a hotel shuttle till 530pm which makes it easier getting into the main areas.  Also there is a airport bus stop just round the corner.  Much easier to get to Kansai airport then using the trains and changing multiple times.

Really nice, there was no one there too so we took a whole hour to take pictures!
There were katanas and a selfie post that were really fun to use. Nice little hike to get there (650m from the road), would recommend for all Demon Slayer fans!!

"Ew weebs"
-Gabi PC, 202X
No way!!!! Is Kamado Tanjiro real???!!!! 😆

I had seen it somewhere before, so I wanted to go there. You may have even appeared on TV.

It is located in the mountains of Yagyu Town in Nara Prefecture, and you can reach the entrance by car, but it is a 680 meter walk from there.

There is a shrine when you go up the cedar forest, but if you go further back there is Yagyu Ittoseki.
It's strange because there are so many strange megaliths.

I don't know exactly why it's so neatly cracked, but somehow I feel calm in the quiet place, and I feel like there's something different about the atmosphere.

Admission is free, but there is a paid parking lot nearby.

If you have a small car, you can get close.
People with bad feet are grateful.

In front of the sign at the entrance, I was told that I couldn't go any further, but as I continued walking, there was a place where I could make a U-turn at the top.
It didn't say that entry was prohibited.

I felt that the influence of Demon Slayer became quite strong and Yagyu became thinner. It seemed like there were a lot of young people and couples coming. It's true that you can go on a motorcycle if you want to, but I think it will be a nuisance to passersby. I parked next to a private house downstairs and walked about a kilometer. I think it's worth going.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒630-8012 Nara, Nijōōjiminami, 1-chōme−3−１ ミ・ナーラ ４F
data.name: NARA KINGYO MUSEUM

reviews.text:
If you like gold fish, this would be a great  place for you to spend for an afternoon. See how they present their cute gold fish in different settings and environment. There are free lockers in the museum, but it is just a small one for your personal belongings.
After that, please be remembered to shop around the G/F supermarket. The goods there are surprisingly economic. See the sushi I got there. You could never buy the same at this price elsewhere.

I did this art aquarium as well as the art aquarium in Ginza. I'd have to say I like this one more. If going to the park to see the deer this is well worth adding to the days itinerary. Bigger than expected. Had multiple themed areas that were very creative and fun to see. Good place to sit down and rest to just enjoy the environment as well. Interactive places for pictures. The disco room was great.

The goldfish museum is conveniently situated on the 4th floor of Mi Nara shopping mall in Nara prefecture, making it easily accessible for visitors.

Upon purchasing an entrance ticket priced at approximately ¥1,200 per person, guests are treated to a captivating display of goldfish tanks housed within intricately decorated rooms. Each room features unique themes such as the crystal, traditional kimono patterns, flowers and seasonal motifs, providing ample opportunities for stunning photographs.

While the goldfish themselves are certainly a sight to behold, what truly sets this museum apart is its attention to detail in creating visually stunning setups. Whether you're a goldfish enthusiast or simply appreciate beautiful aesthetics, this museum is sure to leave a lasting impression.

Wonderful experience. It's a lot less crowded than the one in Ginza, so it was much more peaceful and we were able to take our time a lot more here. Staff were friendly, and there are many sections to this place. It's also located in a plaza so there's a lot of food options or shopping you could do afterwards/beforehand.

It was really beautiful. The exhibition was located on 4F. It didn't have a clear direction on the sign, so it was a little bit difficult for foreigners.

The price of the entrance is a little bit high for the size. It is more appropriate for 2+ people. There are many photo opportunities, but only if you have a friend/partner to help you take pictures.

Overall, the atmosphere was really great. The variety of goldfish was amazing. I highly recommend it for couples or families.

It is located in a quiet residential area. A museum with a quiet and refreshing atmosphere. The focus was on modern Japanese works, and I was happy to see works by my favorite Tadayoshi Sato. It's also nice to just relax and look at the scenery outside the window.

A museum that looks like a small private residence. It is a structure that goes down from the entrance. There are exhibition rooms on the first floor and basement, with a space in the middle facing a large window that offers a view of Frogmata Pond in the back. It was great to see some rare collections.

If you arrive about 30 minutes before opening,
It looks like they made an effort to open it early.
It felt good.

It's small, but it was quite worth seeing.
The bronze statue ``Young Woman Summer'' is good.
There are only 3 parking spaces, so if you want to see the Yamato Bunkakan, I think it's best to park there and walk.
There were discount tickets available at the Shohaku Museum of Art. General 600 yen → 400 yen, 1 ticket for 2 people.
There is also a 100 yen discount on this homepage.
``When entering the museum, please print this screen or present this screen on your smartphone at the reception desk.'' Therefore, it is essentially 500 yen for the general public.
It's a small museum, but perhaps because it was late, I was the only one there with another person. There aren't many works, but I enjoyed watching them slowly.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒630-8012 Nara, Nijōōjiminami, 1-chōme−1−３−１ ミ・ナーラ ５階
data.name: Nara City Museum of Art

reviews.text:
Supermarket
Nice 👌
It is located on the 5th floor of Mi Nara. The exhibition room is very spacious and quiet, so it's perfect for relaxing. Various planned exhibitions are held here.

Today, there was an exhibition called ``The World of Yoshitaka Okada,'' a picture book author.
I saw it in the morning and thought it was interesting, so I went in the afternoon as well, as I had heard that the artist would be there in the afternoon.

He was a friendly teacher and answered all my questions.
He may have drawn things that appeared in his dreams, or his son may have appeared in his works...
Even though it is a surreal painting, there is something warm about it, which I think reflects the artist's personality.

The show is on until August 27th, so why not check it out?
It was free.
Mi. It's on the 5th floor of Narara!

The entrance is wide and flat, so I thought it would be easy for people in wheelchairs and strollers to enter.
There are lockers with a 100 yen refund, so I think it's great that you can view the exhibits while being light.
It's empty on weekdays.
The exhibition space is very quiet and clean.
However, Round One is next door, so on holidays when that place is crowded, the sound of bowling can be heard near the entrance.
Sufficient space is perfect for a gallery

In a traditional house you’ll find tables with traditional toys - and you can play with everything.  The toys have been recreated from historical drawings & are all simple wooden items. Good fun for kids and adults!

An old traditional Japanese house converted into a toy museum. Staffed by very friendly (mostly) elderly Japanese who go out of their way (using translators) to explain how to play the traditional toys. Very interesting and fun experience, could spend an hour here. All young and old will enjoy :)
We had an enchanting visit here with our 6 year old daughter. All the toys are hands-on and Dr Jimmy was super helpful.
This is such an interesting museum, the mechanical toys displayed are traditional toys replicated by university students, my 13 year old son had a great time here

I accidentally walk into this street with a little toy museum. Went in as it was free admission (ended up leaving a donation because it was so nice). And I'm happy I did! The toy museum made my day. Cute interesting historical toys. Very friendly atmosphere and amazing staff! This place makes you smile!

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒630-8212 Nara, Kasuganochō, ５０ 奈良国立博物館 内地下 回廊
data.name: Museum Shop, Nara National Museum

reviews.text: Great spot for a free rest stop. Soft lighting, quiet environment, clean display & set-up. Air-conditioning during the hot summer. Clean bathroom. Café available.
This is a nice cafe in the basement of the Nara national museum. They have a nice menu and are a good space to relax for a bit even if you didn't went to the museum before.
A cool little gift stop. They have a nice collection that feature images / designs from a range of items in the museum. its got some nice scenery around the place too.

When it's a popular event, there are a lot of people, so it's a bit of a wait 💧Accessories, bags, ties, scarves, postcards, stationery, fans, glasses, cups, there are so many things! The books are rich in variety and are worth reading. It's usually a quiet and elegant shop.

I decided to take a look at the underground corridor since it was free, and it was the perfect place to take a break from walking tired feet, with small exhibits, benches, a cafe, and a museum shop with interesting books.
It's a quiet and calm place, very nice.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒630-8208 Nara, Suimonchō, １００ 東大寺総合文化センター内
data.name: Todai-ji Museum

reviews.text:
An Interactive shrine within the Nara Deer Park. You can try to pass through a small hole if you want to.

You can also place your intentions near the entrance hall.

The museum houses a notable collection of artifacts, particularly the Amitabha, which exudes an atmosphere of liberation and non-attachment. Regrettably, the institution's strict adherence to copyright regulations prohibits photography on its premises.

If you are also visiting the Tōdai-ji Buddhist temple, it is advisable to purchase the bundle ticket package, as it grants access to both the temple and the museum.

¥800 per adult for a very small museum. Comparing to other museums in Japan this price is far more for far less.

Make sure to put this money into entering Todai-Ji Daibutsuden Hall instead. This is where you can see the Great Bronze Buddha. Which is suppose to be the largest Bronze Buddha in the world.

This museum has some absolutely exquisite pieces,  especially the Amitabha whose expression blazes with the freedom of non attachment. Unfortunately the authorities, who seem to be heavy with the fog of attachment to their copyright rights, do not allow photos nor provide postcards.
It's a must visit for Indians, it's great to see so many Sanskrit words that we have commonly heard in India like sahasrabhuja, Amitabh, Saraswati, apsara, Dhritarashtra, and many more

They give chance to play Sumo in proper attire
Good memories
For those that love sumo, and even for those that are new to the sport, this was a great attraction. To actually see the ring (dohyō) up close & personal was fantastic!

One of the most memorable experiences in Japan. I attended an outing organized by Nara Kokusaikouryu and Katsuragi-shi. We were welcomed really warmly  and given tea and mochi. We listened to a local group of sumo-jinku singers and then had an introduction to Sumo wrestling by a local sumo-wrestler. After describing the different moves etc we watched a few bouts in the ring with two local sumo-wrestlers. We were also allowed to give it a go ourselves, in a sumo suit as well as try on the sumo attire. The sumo-wrestler also showed us around the museum  and took our questions. All in all a top quality experience.
Amazing experience. It's a sumo dojo and they really explain the sport clearly with demonstration.

The parking lot is located to the west of the Sumo Hall. Just walk north from the Taima Police Box intersection and you'll be right there.

It's free as soon as you enter.
The entrance fee for the dohyo is 300 yen (as of January 2024).

You can step into the ring or come in a sumo wrestler costume and sprinkle salt. You can sit in mass seats.

There were exhibits where you could learn about the history of sumo.

There is wi-fi. It's worth coming if you like sumo.

In the scorching summer, there's a Starbucks nearby where you can enjoy a great view of the lake. Just be aware, there's no shade to shield you from the sun, so sunscreen is a must. ☀️🏞️ #SummerSpot #LakeView
