Nice peaceful place to sip a coffee. It's also near the Starbucks, so one can easily get a coffee from nearby and take a stroll around this pond.
Tranquil space to rest while walking around Nara park… there’s a Starbucks looking at the pond 😉
There are a few benches around the pond where you can seat and relax. Nice vibe at night.
Hôtel is big. Couldn't go inside i havn't a Riom. There IS a legend. Nara grenat place, please Come in!

Sarusawa-ike (Sarusawa Pond) is a tranquil lake in the center of Nara with views of the five-story pagoda of Kofukuji Temple, which reflects in the water when the pagoda is illuminated at night.

I recommend visiting at night to get the full experience.

Sarusawa-ike Pond, also known as Sarusawa Pond, is located in Nara, Japan. It is a scenic pond situated near the famous Todai-ji Temple and Nara Park. The pond is renowned for its serene atmosphere, surrounded by lush greenery and cherry blossom trees. It is a popular spot for locals and tourists alike to enjoy leisurely walks and admire the natural beauty of the area. The pond is relatively small in size but holds significant cultural and historical significance in Nara's landscape.
I'm wondering whether I should go here during the day or at night.  In the end, I went there day and night over two days.  Just stare at the Starbucks right in front for at least 10 minutes.
I just happened to come here during my morning walk when nothing else was open. Quite a scenic place, very nice and quiet in the mornings, good place to have a morning walk and coffee.
No deers at this area, but definitely refreshing to look at

data.formatted_address: Mount Yoshino, Yoshinoyama, Yoshino, Yoshino District, Nara 639-3115, Japan
data.name: Mount Yoshino

reviews.text: The most stunning view of the cherry blossom season. Take two buses from the Yoshino Station all the way to the top, and then hike down the nearly straight path.

Must be so extremely beautiful with the cherry blossoms next month. I didn’t regret visiting Mount Yoshino on 21.03.2024 despite no cherry blossoms yet..

Highly recommend “blue symphony train”on the way back.. totally worth the experience.
The cherry blossom views are worth the struggle through the crowd. A decent 2 hours uphill hike to the highest observatory was worth.

So I went today, April 9, 2024.

The trees are in full bloom and absolutely stunning! My pics are from two spots: the Hanayagura observation deck and the Yoshimizu shrine.

To get to the first, you walk uphill, but it’s quieter. Easy to take as many epic shots as you want. The latter is easy to access (downhill from the shuttle station), but much more crowded. Amazing pics, though!
Try to get there early— maybe 9:30 am.

Less than what I expected.  It must be good in cherry blossoms.
Recommend to take roll-way and bus up, then walk down.  Bus runs hourly.  No bus at noon for two hours.  Rec: Get to the bus stop before 11:30 am.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒630-2205 Nara, Yamabe District, Yamazoe, Matsuo, 桐山３２
data.name: Wanpaku Zoo

reviews.text: We were there 17 Nov 2019. Very lovely village ambience and good food. We had Hamburg and pork cutlet which were well-presented and served with very generous helpings of fresh and delicate salad. Value for money. We also bought some breads from the connecting bakery next door.

reviews.author_name: スプラットブライアン（Brian）
reviews.text: Cute little cafe and petting zoo. Makes a great rest stop on the way in or out of Nara.
Small petting zoo in a farm setting.

A really hidden gem. You can interact with animals up close! It's so close that you'll be surprised!?️ There's also a cafe where you can enjoy cute breads and sweets. I was surprised that there was a spot in the mountains where you could play for free.

I visited on a weekend in December. The parking lot has about 10 spaces and is almost full. This is a popular zoo. Admission is free. You can experience feeding for 100 yen. It is impressive to see cute animals such as ducks, rabbits, and goats playing lively. All the staff were also very kind. You can buy bread and cakes at the attached shop. It was a very relaxing and warm zoo.

2021 / 11/ 20 (16:15) ( Saturday ) ( sunny 🌞 day)
Best free park and relaxing place with free car 🚗 parking lot ever . A little inside the city but worth visiting . It is very big park. There is a cattle house also for free entry . They have cows 🐄 , goats 🐐, lamb 🐑, hen 🐔 , rabbits 🐇, hamsters 🐹, horses 🐴. There were many people with kids. Good place to enjoy whole Saturday with family or friends. You can give food to goats 🐐 or lamb 🐑 for free. Car 🚗 parking is near and free . Toilet 🚽 is available everywhere and convenient and cleaner 🧼 than other normal parks . Vending machines are available. Cafeteria is also available. Better carry cash 💰. Wheelchair ♿️ persons are ok 👌. This park opens till 17:00 but it will fun if you come by 14:00 because they saw cows 🐄 and horse 🐴 out of the cattle by 15:00. Staff were young and polite . Park is very clean 🧼. There were sits so you can relax . There was a big kids slide I have ever seen in any normal park . Fountain ⛲️ also available but we went on winter 🥶 so the fountain ⛲️ was closed I think that will open only in summer . The view is beautiful. Must go place .

Great park if you want to see animals. They have a few animals such as pony, chickens, rabbits and goats. For the goats you can feed them for free. Also a great place for kids since they have a slide and play area for them. Parking is free as well.

Couldn’t actually interact with the animals! They’re all fenced off, and when we tried to pet the mini horses, we got yelled at. Definitely not for foreigners as all signage is in Japanese, and when we asked (in Japanese using Google Translate, we got nowhere.)
2 stars for Free parking & admission, but you get what you pay for. Good bathrooms, but no garbage bins.

Uda Animal Park is a must-visit destination for animal lovers. Located in the scenic mountains of Uda, Nara, the park offers a unique opportunity to see a variety of animals up close in their natural habitats.

The park is well-maintained and clean, and the animals are well-cared for. The staff is knowledgeable and friendly, providing interesting and informative facts about the animals.

Another popular attraction is the petting zoo, where visitors can interact with domestic animals such as goats and rabbits. The zoo is a hit with children and provides a fun and educational experience.

Overall, I highly recommend Uda Animal Park to anyone looking for a fun and unique experience in Uda. The park is family-friendly and suitable for all ages. Don't forget to bring your camera to capture the amazing moments with the animals!

This park is supported both by Uda City and Nara Prefecture, and is a wonderful petting zoo including horses, cows, sheep, goats, pigs, and rabbits.  Riding a horse or pony for one lap is free, as is feeding the sheep and goats with hay provided.  There is a small fee for making your own butter, though milking the cows is no charge.  Except for summer vacation and summer weekends, it's generally not too crowded, staff are very friendly and knowledgeable, and animals well looked after and healthy looking.  There are also sometimes special events, we enjoyed the seeing eye dog experience very much.  Very highly recommended!

The animals looked depressed and sad, a lot of them clawing at the doors desperate to get out (pictures attached). One of the animals' underbelly was covered in sores (picture attached). The enclosures are too small. I was quite sad after watching them desperate to escape. They shouldn't be in there. It was clean with clear paths and lots of toilets throughout that park. Staff were nice. The matcha dipping dots were nice.

The ticket price is 500 yen which isn't alot. The zoo is not the biggest but does have about 20 to 30 different types of animals. I came here on the Tuesday and there isn't anyone here. Also the zoo seems to have part of the attraction cordon off due to bird flue etc and there are renovations ongoing in some part of the zoo. Overall I give this 4/5 for the good pricing..

The photos of the animals I have took and attached in this review for your views.

Under construction. Clean restrooms.  Animals are getting better cages.  Polar bear, Hippo, giraffe, monkeys… gift shop also very good. Cafeteria also served Japanese food.  Lots of snacks around the park. ¥500 entrance.

Costs only 500 yen and you can spend over half a day there. The zoo is very clean and well maintained even a little bit small. It’s understandable since it’s an old zoo, still they are working on expanding the facilities. Would recommended to go.

Located in the heart of the Tennoji area, this spot is incredibly accessible. The majority of the animals you'll find here are birds, making it a paradise for avian enthusiasts. Best of all, entry is free with the Osaka Amazing Pass, allowing you to explore without any additional cost.

---

Very good tourist information centre. Get everything that you need for your Nara trip. And for muslim, do take note they provide prayer area for men and women. Ask the information counter and they will guide you to the prayer area. As for trip to Nara Park, take bus no 2 just next  to the station, it will take you straight to Nara Park for 220 yen.

The bathroom could use some improvement in terms of cleanliness. On a positive note, the receptionist was friendly and exceptionally helpful. Conveniently located beside Starbucks, making it an ideal meeting point.
A great service! One of the few, structured and well organized service that I had in Japan in one month time. The lady was just perfect! Thank you!

my family and I haven't visited Nara for so long and wanted to come back to this beautiful city, although the I did some research on what to do and where to go I'd like to reconfirm it with the tourist information center. I went into the middle counter and this lady was very unwelcoming from the start, no smile no greetings. I open the map and reconfirm with her which is the best route to go and she just hand me a leaflet use a pencil to mark on it and actually say "you can go read it yourself" and "do you need anything else" with a stern face. I've visited Japan more than 20times in my life and have never met a Japanese with this attitude. I decided to just go over the next counter because the lady next to her explains everything so throughly and was very welcoming and kind.
don't go to this lady she's extremely unhelpful with poor attitude. she shouldn't be working here.

It is located beside the train station with a Starbucks beside it. Walked in to ask for information about Heijo Palace since we were there during the New Years period. You just needed to walk to the right counter to get a person who can help you in your language.
It is also just outside the bus depot so quite handy to find the right bus to get you to the right attraction.

data.name: Private car tour in Kyoto, Nara and Osaka

reviews.text: Best Kyoto tour guide there is! An amazing guide and driver who makes Kyoto feel quiet and intimate even during tourist season. Find the popular spots when they're quiet, and hidden gems only a local would know. You'll see more with Kosuke in a day than in 2 days on your own, especially if you're traveling with a group. He's so helpful and knowledgeable about the the city and the sites. Even finding nice spots to eat and drink after the tour.
Lovely food, really nice hospitality. Must try the sorbet, it was amazing!!
Good recluse tourist spot

Nara Town is located south of Sarusawa Pond, around Gangoji Temple, and is located a little over 10 minutes from Kintetsu Nara Station and less than 20 minutes from JR Nara Station, and even if you take a light stroll, you can cross it in about an hour. It's a good walking course.
The intersections may be straight or intricate, and the walls may be earthen walls or blocks. There are wooden doors and aluminum doors. There are mansions and modern houses, and it's a mix of things, but it's full of flavor and a sense of life, and you can enjoy it.
Of course, there is no trash left, and the alleys and gardens have been sprinkled with water, and even the small potted plants have been taken care of, making them look lively.

Nara has a history of over 1200 years. Looking at the earthen walls of the temples and shrines, which still have their original divisions, as well as the aged tiles and pillars, it has a character that sets it apart not only from Edo, but also from Kamakura and Kyoto. For some reason, Nara has an overwhelming dignity.

It has become a tourist spot, with cafes, general stores, clothing stores, and long-established restaurants that take advantage of the old townscape.
Koshin-san will also be a place to worship at Gangoji Temple.
It's a place with a nostalgic feel and sophisticated products, making it a great place to chill out and walk around.

Naramachi is an area where many of Nara's old private houses and townscapes remain. It is dotted with old folk houses, restaurants, souvenir shops, temples, and shrines. I want to take my time and walk all day long.

An almost dead shopping street from the old times. A few shops are still surviving. I wish more people would go and buy from there so it stays in business and doesn’t vanish. I found an old Chinese ramen shop, a fruits and vegetables shop, a flower shop and a meat shop still open when I visited today. I got goosebumps when I saw the ghost shops with their worn out curtains, signposts and interior of what once was thriving with life.
Nothing much there... most places are closed and run down ...

It is often said that ancient capitals are ``a fusion of old and new,'' and this is probably true when looking at the city as a whole, whether it's Kyoto or Nara. However, when it comes to this place, the combination of antiquity and oldness creates a magical atmosphere. There are some new cafes and traditional Chinese restaurants, but many of them are shuttered and some have even collapsed. The passageway is wide enough for two people to walk side by side, and it's dark even during the day, making it a strange space where you can hear the hustle and bustle of the city in the distance. I think this is a place that will probably impress people who like ruins.

I took a stroll through Tsubakii Market in Nara City, which has a history of over 125 years.
.
The shopping street has a nostalgic atmosphere, and there are several stores still open today, making it an area where you can enjoy a unique atmosphere👾
.
There is a flower garden right in the middle that you can freely tour ♪ Marigolds and sunflowers were blooming beautifully 👾
*Visitors are allowed only between 9:00 and 16:00.

Some houses are on the verge of collapse due to aging...
I don't know how many more typhoons I can survive. This is the road I want to take just now to soak up the nostalgic atmosphere.
It must have been prosperous in the past...
There is a small shrine so you can visit there.
Public toilets are extremely dirty and women should not use them.

I don't think the abandoned fish shop will last for many more years.
It says 24 hours open everyday in google maps but its closed…. The hours should be updated properly.
The parking lot is large and the store is spacious.

I arrived at the market right away, but I couldn't find the store, so I searched a lot.In the end, I asked the people at the market and they said it was on the 2nd floor.I climbed up the slope to the 2nd floor, and there were so many delicious-looking menu items that I got lost. However, I ordered the special chirashi and ate it.It was huge and delicious. I would like to try other menu items as well.

I went there because it was Shokusai City.
I arrived late at around 10:45, and many of the stores were closed.
It starts at 8:30 and many customers will arrive around 8 o'clock.
I think I'll go early for the next Shokusai City on March 30th.
The parking lot is large and easy to park, but it was not kept well-maintained and there was a lot of trash.
I was looking for a restaurant where I could eat delicious seafood bowls, but I couldn't find it, so I asked the people at the market and they said it was like the rooftop of the market, so I went there.
There was a restaurant called Shunke.
I had the medium tuna tuna bowl for 1,800 yen and the button shrimp salmon roe bowl for 1,200 yen, and they were delicious.
There are other bowl menus as well.
I think the price is also quite low. The staff are very friendly and this store is ★★★★★. I think it's better to ask people in the market because it's not noticeable.
Business hours are Saturdays, weekdays from 5:00 to 15:00, Sundays and public holidays from 9:00 to 15:00.

February 23, 2019

I participated in the 45th anniversary festival.
I was satisfied because I was able to buy local Nara vegetables and specialty products, as well as specialty products from other prefectures, at low prices.
We enjoyed a simulated auction experience, a tuna butchering show, and Tokushima's Awa Odori dance.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒630-8215 奈良県奈良市東向中町１５
data.name: Higashimuki Shopping Street

reviews.text: Located in the and near the Old Traditional Shopping old area called Naramachi this is a wonderful place to see all sort of arts, crafts, calligraphy and many old traditional houses. After seeing so many Nara Temples this was a very welcome change.
The market's integration of its history with the Nara city was well-received. I am delighted to have discovered this market.

A convenient marketplace for souvenir and food shopping awaits you between Nara Station and Nara Park, making it easily accessible during your stroll in the area.

When i visited here Dec 30 2023, most of the shops are closed, part of the long holudays in Japan from Dec 29 to Jan 3.

A convenient shopping district just beside the kintentsu Nara line. You'll find plenty of nice restaurant with Various menu. Feel free to try out and most of them will require queuing at peak hours. Tax free shop available too at the area.
There is alot restaurant here. Very nice walk.and you may find famous mochi here also
A must go place for souvenir.
Since it was a weekend, it was crowded with people. There are many restaurants, but there is also a Nara product store.
Located right next to Kintetsu Nara Station. It's an arcade street, so it's comfortable even in bad weather. It is filled with many restaurants, Nara souvenirs, and fancy shops.

``Tendon Makino Nara Higashimuki Branch'' in front of Kintetsu Nara Station, Higashimuki Shopping District
Tendon Ro 1375 yen I was thirsty so I had Kirin barley tea ✨🍺 Lots of ingredients such as large conger eel, shrimp, fried squid & small fish, eggs, etc. 😳
Oh! Before that, the old lady next to me said, ``I ordered tempura bowl, but it's a lot, so please eat it!'' I couldn't refuse the Showa-style offer, so I shared the tempura, salmon, and shishito peppers, so I had a hefty serving of tempura. . Stomach full

This is a shopping street that I often go to.
There are plenty of souvenir shops and restaurants.
It is crowded with tourists and locals.

data.name: Nara National Museum Nara Buddhist Sculpture Hall

reviews.text: Located in the Nara Park this Museum is packed full of marvellous statues, some even dating back to the very early years of Buddhism in Japan. A treasure house of highest art. I also loved the didactical efforts and exhibition in the basement, where extremely charming staff members hand out a quiz to learn more about the meaning of the statues, but also of the ways and means they were created. They even show samples of Japanese trees used for the statues and their wood. They all have distinctive scents and even sounds! Loved it! The restauant offers nice food and sweets on exquisite dishes, and the shop offers lovely crafted useful souvenirs and books.

It was great to experience all of the Buddhist sculptures with some great information describing the different types of sculptures and history behind them.

The new wing was not open when we visited but the length of the Buddhist sculpture exhibit is great if you have people that aren’t overly interested in a long museum visit as I did.

It's quite impressive, there are so many collections of Buddha and bodhisattva statues that are dated to the 9 century. Even a free thinker like me felt like being a Buddhist after visiting the museum.
Personally not too interested in these kinds of buildings but this is great! It has a good balance of free and paid stuff to give us a teaser of what we can expect.
Nice ancient Egyptian remake at universal studio. Fun place to spend time. Highly recommend
Axle and wheels form a monument

There are beautiful weeping cherry blossoms surrounding the Daibutsu Railway Monument. There are 4 pieces. It looks as if everything is connected, which is impressive.

Due to its location, it is difficult to take a leisurely view or take photos as the power lines tend to be reflected in the view and get in the way of traffic, but it is a place you should definitely stop by while admiring the cherry blossoms along the Saho River.

It is quite difficult to capture the whole cherry blossom tree, but the best way to take a good photo without obstructing traffic is to stand at the end of a narrow alley to the southeast of the cherry tree and hold the camera facing northwest. .

If you stop by by bicycle, there is a little space at the east and west ends of the park, so it would be a good idea to park your bicycle there. It might get in the way a little if it's on the side of the road.
I had no idea what I was writing. I think the area along the Saho River is beautiful during the cherry blossom season.

This is a historical park that was the site of a station on the Kansai Railway Daibutsu Line that ran from Kamo Station to Daibutsu Station from 1890 to 1909. It feels like the junction of a Y-junction has been turned into a park, and the area is about the size of a small children's park. The surrounding area is residential. The park has a driving wheel that is thought to be of the same type as the Daibutsu Railway, and a retro-shaped streetlight hidden behind cherry trees, giving it a small but elegant feel.

When I arrived, I was surprised to find that although Daibutsu Station is located, it is quite far from the Todaiji Daibutsu Hall. Unexpectedly, I thought that the reason Daibutsu Railway was discontinued after 9 years was due to the poor location of Daibutsu Station.

If I were a person in Kamo in the 1900s, I probably wouldn't have used the Daibutsu Railway because it would be inconvenient if the terminal station was here.

It is located at the end (starting point) of a row of cherry blossom trees along the Saho River, and you can see very beautiful cherry blossoms in spring.
It is located at an irregular intersection, so there are many cars passing by, so please be careful.
Machiya gallery

data.formatted_address: Jl. Setia Budi No.96 B, Tj. Rejo, Kec. Medan Sunggal, Kota Medan, Sumatera Utara 20122, Indonesia
data.name: Nara art gallery

reviews.text: Friendly staff, interesting selection
Bro, can you sell jars?

Wow what a stunning curation!!! We're absolutely in love with this place. From modern to traditional, you've got a great sample for everything.

Well worth the admission fee - 400 or free for foreigners (visitors or residents), disabled people and some other categories.

Will be back for sure.
Nice place.... Good collection of popular arts in the world.

A nice art museum and is free for foreign visitors! Staff were very kind and friendly ( there was even someone at the end who took my picture next to an exhibit sign). Exhibition likely rotates. There was even a mini music concert out front which they also invited me to attend.
We loved the exposition. Friendly service at front desk and gift shop. Lockers available. Free entrance for foreigners (bring passport).
It's an old building, so it smells a little bit. The good part of this art museum is that it is free for foreigners with a valid ID. We went today for an exhibition, and it was ok.

data.name: Irie Taikichi Memorial Museum of Photography Nara City

reviews.text: After visiting the former residence of Irie Taikichi, I continued my journey on knowing more on the photographer by paying a visit to his name sake photography gallery. The architecture itself is very special, with a large open pond and terrace field-like slopes. And the permanent exhibition is a powerful tool to display the great photographer’s love for the Yamato Road, or, simpler, Nara.
It is pretty far from the major sights and the exhibition is average. If you are on a rushed schedule, you can skip it.
Boring museum with not a very creative display. The building is nice though the exhibits are ordinary. Generic landscape images and bw portraits.
took me 3 minutes to get water running when washing hands. Not fun when you have soap all over  your hands.
Great place for photography lovers!

data.name: Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties

reviews.text: Cool view from the train

This is the main office building of the Nara Research Institute for Cultural Properties, affectionately known as "Nabunken." This new building was completed in 2018 after being used as a temporary government building in the park in order to accommodate the full-scale excavation of the Heijo Palace Ruins, a special historic site that is also a World Cultural Heritage Site, which will become a national park.

Information is also disseminated on Youtube's ``Nabunken Channel'', and we are enjoying the content unique to the institute. A corner introducing the remains and excavated items found on the site, introduced in ``The History of the Construction of the Nabunken Main Office Building,'' has been set up at the entrance of the entrance building, and is open to the public for viewing free of charge.

I looked twice at the wooden tablet with the words ``Narakyo'' written on it.

The attached museum is the Heijo Palace Ruins Museum in the park, and it has exhibits including a replica of the "Hayato's Shield" and is free of charge. You can get pamphlets about the park at the main building, so it's the best location for those coming on foot from Saidaiji Station.

I'm a local resident.
The lawnmower is extremely noisy from 7am in the morning, and there are days when the trucks are opening and closing repeatedly until around 11pm at night, probably because they are transporting the property.
Before researching Nara's cultural assets, please ensure that the citizens of the prefecture live a healthy life.

It's a fine building.
It's better than the crappy prefectural and city halls.
As expected from Nara Prefecture!

I wish it were more open.

Advance reservations are required to use the library, and I have heard that there is a limit of 2 to 3 people per day.
There is an exhibition space for excavated items in one corner of the reception floor.
Serene and poetic garden, not big, but enough for a leisure walk among the ponds and pine trees. Entry fee 200 yen for adult.
ok
Beautiful garden Wisteria was blooming

Free for exhibition only. It costs 200 yen to enter the garden.
The exhibition space is a large room with many panels but also exhibits, and a hallway space on the second floor (stairs, shoes must be taken off).
The area is designated as a scenic spot and is approximately 13,000 square meters, so most of it is a garden. The toilet looks old, but has been renovated.

It's enough to be designated as a scenic spot, but it's a garden that doesn't have many stones. The bridge may be a dead end.

There is a fee for the garden, but the cultural center is free. You can see a diorama that recreates the old Daijo-in Temple. There is also a tea room and conference room (for a fee) that can be used for special events, making it a base for local cultural activities.

This place was not on my go to list as i had not seen it recommended, but i happened to walk past it and decided to go inside. I'm so glad i did. I really hope that some day it will be noticed by an influencer as it's been my favorite experience in Japan so far. Even though the staff struggled with English, I got a tour explaining to me many details about Shiga Naoya, how the house was built and how it was used. Not only did it teach me about this author, the way the house was set up also gave insights into the Japanese culture of that time.

What a beautiful home! Everything is well kept and taking the length to restored. The hand out also gives one a very clear idea on each and every room, on the history, the owner and fun details. Visitors are few and you could take your time to explore this big house and it’s two gardens on your own. A hidden treasure it is.
Great old house
Knowledgeable director who also compiled the book for Shiga memorabilia, speaks good English and has great insight on the Japanese aesthetics tradition. Beautiful tranquil neighborhood
Japanese writer's house. Big enough. Well reserved.

The garden was ok. There was not a lot going on. It didn’t feel very botanical, more like a public school garden. There was a Japanese ceremony being demonstrated on the dock with live music that was very impressive and gave an unreal feeling while in a Japanese garden. The forest is a few km up the road which was well worth the walk. The walk up the road takes you the long way but it was well worth it. It does a full loop so you will end up at the main park. 1-2 hours of walking.

This is a marvelous gem in Nara park.
No any deer inside, only outside:)))
Very peaceful and calm environment, beautiful scenery.

A small sealed off section of Nara Park. ¥500 entry is steep given there is not a great deal to see inside. I paid ¥100 for the last bag of fish food in the honesty box by the pond. I enjoyed feeding the Koi one by one and had a rest for about 30 minutes.

Staff were mowing and whipper snipping the whole time I was there which detracted from what would have been a peaceful ambience. Nobody else in the park except me and a tourist couple who insisted on having a prolonged snogg session in all locations. Respect local culture and limit your PDAs!!

Better off finding a quiet spot in Nara Park (free) if you want a break from the crowds. No deers inside botanical gardens.

This place was very beautiful it’s small compared to other gardens I’ve been to but it has very unique spots you can take photos and the lagoon with the fish is so beautiful to seat around relax and admire.. I definitely recommend this place! It’s not crowded it’s very calm and relax. You can have a nice afternoon walking around there…

This very large and beautiful garden is worth its entrance fee. They also sell potted plants and wisteria bonsai trees. Recommended if you’re local. I go here every year to experience the wisteria and see various local plants. It may be educational for kids to learn and remember how different vegetables and fruits grow, as usually, you have to go to the countryside or a farm to see this.

The beautiful and cute koi fish are adorable. I’d suggest they sell fish food in a gacha machine to earn some extra income and provide more fun for visitors.

If you’re really into nature, it may be a great place to visit with kids to search for frogs and lizards. However, please remember to behave appropriately since this is private property, not a playground. Please be responsible and respect the love and care for nature that this garden displays.

As a foreigner who has lived in Japan for almost a decade, I’ve seen enough inappropriate behavior from foreign tourists in Nara. Nara is like a sacred heaven for the Kansai region.
Have a good time and enjoy the beauty of nature.

I visited Tobihino on Friday to see the famous deer at Kasuga Taisha Shrine. There were so many adorable deer roaming around! To interact with them, I purchased a pack of deer cookies for 200 yen.

However, it's important to note that the deer can sometimes be aggressive. If you want to leave, remember to hide your food, as they may become persistent and follow you around. So, exercise caution!

Aside from the deer, Tobihino itself is a beautiful location. The park is filled with natural beauty and has a serene atmosphere. It's the perfect place to relax and enjoy nature. In addition to the shrine, there are also other attractions within the park, like the famous Todaiji Temple.

I recommend taking the time to explore Tobihino and its surroundings. You can also find various food stalls and souvenir shops nearby, offering a taste of local cuisine and unique souvenirs.

Overall, Tobihino is a must-visit destination, especially if you're an animal lover. The experience of interacting with the deer is truly unforgettable, and the park offers a peaceful escape from the bustling city. Don't forget to have your camera ready for some amazing photos with the deer!
Kids love this place. Big space for running and have fun
When is sunset definitely come here since a lot of deers tend to come here. Really close to the Nara park, and is children friendly. One of the best places in Nara for seeing deers.

We arrived about 1pm, there were many deers, by 3:30pm most had gone home.
The deers were not afraid to be touched, very cute. 🦌
Feed the bowing deers and visit multiple temples done in 1-2 hours.

This forest is part of UNESCO world heritage and it's a beautiful hike. If you're coming from Nara Park, you can enter the trail from just east of the restaurant Mizuya Chaya. Going around the whole forest took us about four hours. It will take you to the Wakakusayama hilltop, the Uguisuno-taki waterfall, and then along the southern edge of the forest.

Some more detail: The full circuit is about four hours trek, mostly gravel path or asphalt, but quite a bit of incline in some places. Going from the trail entry to the hilltop takes about an hour, where you'll want to pause to enjoy the view, then another hour or so to get to the waterfall, and another hour and a half trek to the edge of the forest in the southwest. It's possible to meet cars along the way, but we never did, only two mopeds and two bikes along the full circuit. We met a handful of other hikers as well, mostly Japanese.

It's perfect to spend a morning or afternoon. If it's a hot day, don't be discouraged, as the path is almost completely in shade from the trees and the forest is pleasantly cool even on a hot day.

I recommend taking a lot of water along, as we did not see any water taps along the way. There are two restrooms we went by, one on the hilltop (where there are also vending machines with drinks), and one at the reststop on the southeast edge of the forest.

Here’s our adventure to experience the Kasugayama Primeval Forest. I read somewhere that the trail around the forest is about 10km. And some visitors took up to 4 hrs. (We ended up taking more than 5 - excluding the time we took from Nara station to the start of the trail).

We set off from Nara station. There’s a visitor centre above the station where we picked up a map.

Anyway, once we reached Nara Park, we got lost after walking along what we thought was the way to the start of the trail.

We eventually found an entrance further inwards near Satei Yusui, a restaurant near the Mizuya Shrine. This was the Kasugayama Mountain Trail.

The trail was a pretty straightforward gravel path. It became an upslope climb for most of the way and let us to the top of Mount Kasuga. As we neared the top, we saw a sign to turn left to go to the mountain top, and turn right to continue on the trail.

We were glad to have headed to the mountain top. Apart from satisfying our curiosity of the view from the top, there was a toilet and a car park and some vending machines with cold and hot drinks. Good for a recharge.

From the mountain top, there was an option to head down to Nara Park (nearer). Or to continue one round around the forest before returning to Nara Park (much much longer).

We decided to walk the long way, and realize there was a one-way narrow road for cars to drive into the forest. Although they have to pay a toll charge. On our walk, we didn’t see any cars pass us by.

The trail goes down. Which was a relief as we had been walking up quite a bit before that. After awhile, we saw a sign pointing to a waterfall that was 600m away.

So we decided to go. When we heard no water sounds as we walked lower down the trail, we started dreading the thought of having to walk all the way back up. Thankfully, we found the waterfall and did hear the water sounds as we got nearer. This was the Uguisuno-taki falls.

Thankfully, we did not have to retrace our steps, and followed another trail back to the main route.

Apparently, you can drive to a car park nearby, and walk down to the waterfall. This is along the one-way route for cars into the forest. But this stop is a branch off the main road, which cars then have to get back onto.

With the sun about to set in less than 90 minutes, and us barely at the halfway point, we started to walk faster. Haha.

We eventually reached a security post. There was a trail that turned right just before the post that led down to the Takayama Shrine. We took this route as it looked like the shortest way out from the forest.

Along the way, the path split into one that led downwards to a rest stop. We decided to go with that one. The path was rocky and I think it’s a shorter path that followed along the Noto River, compared to the trail we saw on the map that was more windy.

The trail ended and we exited to a small road that led down to houses along the street. We were back in town just before the sun set!

So here’s our thoughts:

- the forest is very nice and majestic.
- You need to give yourself time to enjoy.
- Good walking shoes is a must.
- Limited toilets and rest stops along the trail.
- There’s probably other trails apart from the one we walked along.
- We came across people who were either hiking or jogging.
- Bring water.
- The walk consist of upslopes and downslopes.
- We missed some of the sights and shrines cos we were rushing a bit, and also at times feeling lost.
- Just follow the main route and have your mobile phone with a data plan so you can track where you are along the trail.

Tons of awesome hiking trails up and down the mountain, along with loads of excellent views along the way.  The forest was very mature and beautiful! There were even occasional ruins here and there to spot in the foliage. Definitely bring a camera and some snacks.

From Nara, I hiked up Wakakusa and around the Primeval Forest and back in about 4 1/2 hours. It was a great way to spend a day. The forest is a nice place to escape the city ànd has some lovely spots.
Refreshing and calm walk.

North Gate serves as one of the entrances to Mt Wakakusa.
There are two main climbing trails to Mt Wakakusa (342 above the city). Each of them takes around 15 min. to reach the midway observatory, plus another 20 min. to reach the summit. Mt  Wakakusa is easy to climb but rewards hikers with great views over the surrounding area.
Apparently the best time to visit is in the spring, when cherry trees are blooming. The mountain paths are closed during winter.  The park is open from 09:00 to 16:30. The entrance to the park cost 150 ¥ per adult and 80 ¥ per child.

Been there second time. It is always the best place for me to get close to deer in Nara as less crowded and the view was superb. Mt. Wakakusayama Burning Event in the fourth Saturday in January every year. Yamayaki (burning of a mountain)” is a traditional event that heralds the arrival of early spring in the ancient capital of Nara. The scene of the night sky dyed red with fireworks is worth seeing. But the mountain only open March to Dec, 9am to 5pm. I went there 27 march, play & feed the deer outside the gate with deer food purchased from shop. When I want to enter, i only realised it was over 5pm. So be alert about time playing with deer if you want to enter Mt. Wakakusa! Enter via south gate and exit via north gate. The entrance fee is 150yen only. Dont miss this place!

(Trip was made back then on 21 Nov 2019, 2 years before the Covid-19 Pandemic hit)

This was actually the connecting path I used to get from Nigatsudo to Kasuga Taisha.

On one side is the entrance to Mt Wakakusa, which is dotted with deers lying on the pasture, while the other side are lined with eateries and souvenir shops.

Giving this 5 stars as this is one of two entrances to the Wakakusa Mt walk. It is an easy to follow path and the entrance fee is only 150 yen. In just 15-20 minutes walk you get a view across Nara and beyond. 30- 40 mins to get to the top of Mt Wakakusa. Easy to do with just normal shoes and the added benefit of seeing deer in a more natural habit outside of the city. Open between March and December from 9am-5pm
I just spent the best ¥150 in Nara. Short but very rewarding hike

Walking along the forest path on the Tokai Nature Trail,
From Muroguchi-Oono Station, take the bus route towards Muroji Temple, cross the vermilion Ichinowatari Hashi, and on the right hand side you will see the Tokai Nature Trail information board.From there, the forest path begins. You can head towards Muroji Temple or Muro Dam. A leisurely hike through the forest while listening to the sound of a flowing stream is the most luxurious experience. Why not enjoy a soothing walk along the Tokai Nature Trail without taking the bus from Muroguchi-Ono Station? If you walk for 5 minutes from the station, you will see the impressive statue of Maitreya Bodhisattva carved into a large rock, and you will reach the bus stop near Ono-dera Temple. There is also a very clean toilet here ☓☓It is cleaner than the station. No secret.

data.formatted_address: Taroji, Soni, Uda District, Nara 633-1202, Japan
data.name: Soni Highlands

reviews.text: Such a very very very very beautiful place, this is the first time I got chance to visit the biggest pampas area that I never see it before. Just 200円 for motorbike parking, but I find it really deserves then I pay a double fee ^^ I recommend if you have time in Autumn November, please come to Soni highland for a while to get tons of amazing things!

I went there in the end of Autumn to see silver grasses. It was an amazing experience, it felt like as if i were in a picture or a movie.
I was lucky to find a parking space further down from the site, but there was a long queue for the parking.

Wasn't expecting a charred landscape from the photos on Google maps but that was what I found on an off season visit! I guess they do it to make sure the healthy growth of the landscape for peak tourists seasons. Still a great visit as the views are impressive. Did not attempt the summits but seems to be quite a manageable walk up. Costs 800yen for parking for cars.

Soni Highland in Japan is a picturesque destination that offers a refreshing escape from city life. Nestled in the serene Kansai region, this highland area is known for its stunning landscapes, lush greenery, and outdoor activities.

The standout feature of Soni Highland is its breathtaking views. Whether you visit during the vibrant colors of spring, the cool breezes of summer, or the fiery foliage of autumn, you'll be treated to a panorama of rolling hills, dense forests, and clear skies. The natural beauty here is simply awe-inspiring.

Hiking enthusiasts will find plenty to explore in the surrounding hills and mountains. The hiking trails are well-maintained and offer varying levels of difficulty, making it suitable for both beginners and experienced trekkers. One of the most popular hikes is to Mt. Miune, which rewards climbers with stunning vistas from the summit.

Soni Highland is also famous for its flower fields, particularly in spring when the hills come alive with colorful blooms, including cherry blossoms and rapeseed flowers. It's a fantastic spot for nature photography and picnicking.

The area has several charming guesthouses and traditional ryokans where you can experience Japanese hospitality and cuisine. Enjoying a meal while gazing at the serene countryside is a memorable experience.

However, it's worth noting that Soni Highland is somewhat secluded, so it's advisable to have your own transportation to fully explore the region. Overall, if you're looking for a tranquil and scenic retreat in Japan, Soni Highland offers a perfect blend of natural beauty and outdoor adventure.

I wish i reached the top but i wasnt physically prepared🤣 but the view was awesome. We went there on a holiday, and the traffic was sooo bad. Luckily, google maps led us to a mountain side route that's not traffic.

data.formatted_address: Myojin Falls, Konotani, Kawakami, Yoshino District, Nara 639-3635, Japan
data.name: Myojin Falls

reviews.text: 2023.4 From Country 169, cross Osako Dam and proceed through Prefecture 224. There are generally 1 to 1.5 lanes, but there are many separation points so there is no particular problem. The pavement was clean and there were almost no falling rocks. Cross the Irinohashi Bridge and continue for a while, then turn left at the junction of the Kitamata River and the Honzawa River and enter the forest road along the Kitamata River. From here, the road becomes a single lane with some parts unpaved with many falling rocks. There are quite a few separation points, but you need to be careful as there are places where you can't get close to them if you don't step on falling rocks. Pass the brand new bridge at Okutamadani, cross the Sannoko River bridge and make a sharp right turn. The branch is like a plaza, so you can turn without having to turn back. There are no branches and if you follow the forest road along the Sannokogawa River, there will be a wide space at the end with plenty of room for turns. Once you climb the stairs at the trailhead, there is a well-maintained and clearly marked trail, and there is tape so you don't have to worry about getting lost. There were some decaying wooden bridges that were still under construction, but there was no need to force yourself to cross them as you could take a detour from 𦚰. Although it is maintained, it is still a mountain trail. Shoes and gloves are required as there are narrow areas and rope areas. If you go down to the right at the Y-branch with the broken signboard on the right side of Myojin Falls, you will be in front of the waterfall in 36 minutes from the trailhead. Please be careful as the slope going down is rather steep. It was a model-like direct waterfall, and it was a beautiful waterfall with a drop and a sense of scale that exceeded the numerical values. Prefecture 224 seems to be undergoing construction beyond Kuroishidani and Kaminodani, so there was a surprising amount of traffic including construction vehicles and people fishing, so please be careful of oncoming traffic.

A direct waterfall located deep within Osako Dam.

The drop is around 15m. It was a rainy day and the water was rising, but it didn't seem too severe and the atmosphere was calm. I visited on a gloomy day, but the basin of the waterfall was blue and beautiful. The fallen tree lying in front of the waterfall is a nice touch, and it's a relaxing space with a sense of secluded area.
You can see the entire waterfall from the front, but if you follow the rocky area on the left, you can get much closer to the basin of the waterfall.

It takes about 30 minutes for an adult male to walk from the trailhead to the waterfall. The mountain road has some ups and downs, but it's not that steep.
There are over 20 wooden bridges along the way. Both the old and new bridges are slippery and the old bridges are corroded, so please be careful when walking.

This is a place where there are a lot of bees and flies. Wear clothes that are easy to move in and don't expose your skin. Sneakers are fine, but shoes with thick soles and non-slip soles are more suitable. I think it's better to prepare gloves as there are places where you will have to hold on to the remaining ropes.

The road up to the trailhead is fairly wide and basically paved, but after passing Yamahatoyu, the road surface becomes poor and there are some unpaved parts. There are many cave-ins, so we recommend slowing down.

Parking space available. The toilet is located about 200m before the trailhead. There is no cell phone signal.

You can go down from the trailhead to the river that flows beside the trail, but please be aware that there is a sign that only tour visitors are allowed to enter.
A beautiful waterfall of about 40 meters. It is well worth the 45 minute one-way trip from the trailhead. Be careful of vipers.

A majestic waterfall that suddenly appears along a steep mountain path.
It takes about an hour each way from the start of the climb, with plenty of breaks. The second half of the mountain road has quite dangerous parts. I think it would be better to borrow a cane at the entrance. By the way, there are places where you can definitely die if you fall, so it is not recommended for small children. Also, those who are afraid of heights may have to turn back midway.
Some places have ladders to make it easier to pass, but you should tread carefully so you don't trust them too much.
Please plan with plenty of time. It soon gets dark and you can't find your way. Also, there are bears living here, so it's probably safer to make noise while walking.

Mitaki is located on the way from Sannoko to Kakushidaira. There is a huge rock nearby that is about two stories high. It is said that this rock was called the ``treasure mouth'' and that the sacred seal was hidden in the crevice.

2023.9.15 added
Due to landslides caused by Typhoon No. 7, the road leading to Myojin Waterfall is difficult to pass (there are dangerous spots). Two wooden bridges on the waterfall side have collapsed, and there is a landslide. If you are planning to go to the site, please judge the situation carefully. Additionally, the shape of the waterfall pot has changed significantly. Please see the photo for details.

Added on 2023.12.11
The restoration of the wooden bridge has not yet been completed. There is also a wooden bridge on the verge of collapse.

data.formatted_address: Momoono Falls, Takimotocho, Tenri, Nara 632-0021, Japan
data.name: Momoono Falls

reviews.text:
A beautiful waterfall. Nice shower of water falling into a shallow pool.
Reasonable hike from a nearby road which has some bus service.
Nice place for spending time
The road to the waterfall parking lot is a little narrow so be careful! The waterfall is very impressive and gives you a very sacred feeling!

It feels like there is a dragon wave❗️
When you actually stand in front of the waterfall, some of the trees are swaying ❗️ If the wind is caused by the drop in the water, the surrounding trees will also sway ❗️ And the sudden wind is also a sign of Ryu 🐉 👍️ Ryu quietly stands there. Feel the energy of 🐉 and find the signs.

If you go east on National Route 25 in Tenri City, you will see a sign for ``Momoo Falls''. The road along the way is very narrow, but there is a parking lot right next to the waterfall, so it's convenient. The waterfall has a large amount of water, so much so that you wonder why the water source never dries up. Power spot.

The training ground for Ozune, the role of En.
The training ground of Okiri and Otominokami.
A fugitive from the Hogen Rebellion. The ruins of Lord Fujiwara Yorinaga, Minister of the Left.
There is a signboard.
It's so convenient that you can go there in 2 minutes on foot!
If you are passing by, please stop by and check it out.
Free parking available nearby.

It is a place where you can feel the power of the dragon god!The darkness even during the day makes you feel like you are on a pilgrimage to a sacred place. The closer we get to the waterfall, the colder it gets. It's great in the summer! It cleanses both body and mind.
It was a surprisingly small waterfall.

data.formatted_address: Imai, Soni, Uda District, Nara 633-1212, Japan
data.name: Saijobo Waterfall

reviews.text: Visited on September 1, 2023. It has been almost 40 years since I last visited, but the road has been maintained and is now easy to walk. It's a little steep before the lower waterfall, so comfortable walking shoes are recommended. If you go from the prefectural road, there is a plaza where you can park, but you can't face the other way, so if it gets muddy, you might get addicted to it. After rain, it is best to walk near the prefectural highway. I don't remember much about it, but it was a magnificent waterfall, unlike what I remembered. It's possible that in the past, the road used to be a trail along the river, so you may not have been able to reach it.

There is an information board along Prefectural Route 784, and there is a large parking space at the end of the flat dirt road that can be accessed by car. After walking along the promenade for about 5 minutes, there is a detour due to a landslide, and you can grab a rope and go in front of the waterfall basin, but you cannot see the waterfall from the front. However, it was a pretty impressive waterfall.

"Saijobou no Taki"

There is no parking lot, so you will have to park on the road in the space in front of the promenade to the waterfall.

You can reach the waterfall area in about 10 to 15 minutes by following a nearly straight promenade. The trail is rough, so it's best to wear hiking shoes and take your time.

In front of the waterfall, the road was cut off by a landslide (at the time of my visit around September 2020). From there, you can cross the river to the other side and walk a short distance to reach the waterfall. You can cross the river by jumping along the rocks, but there is also the possibility of slipping, so if you bring shoes that can be submerged in the water, such as rain boots, you will be able to reach the waterfall smoothly. .

The drop is about 10 to 15 meters. Oblique explosion. One of the 36 "Yamato Water" locations selected by the prefecture.

Although I couldn't say that there was a lot of water when I visited, the space in front of the waterfall had a pretty nice atmosphere.

The promenade does not go all the way to the front of the waterfall, so I was only able to take photos from a short distance from the waterfall.

The basin of the waterfall seems to be quite deep, so it will be difficult to face it directly. At first glance, it seems like I could go to the corner wearing boots or something, but I can't say for certain because I just looked into the distance. If you are planning to go, it would be best to make some preparations.

It is said that there used to be a Buddhist temple called Saijobo, where ascetics practiced water to purify themselves and prayed to the spirit of Suen Daifudo Myoo. A valley created by the Yokowa River. A clear waterfall and an emerald green pool are connected.

When I visited, it was around September, but it seems that the autumn leaves are also said to be beautiful.

I went on September 4th.
Last time I went there, I took a straight road and there was Mizukai nearby, so I thought I would take that straight road to Saijobo Falls and arrive there, but instead I ended up driving down a winding mountain road.
You can tell because there is a sign for Saijobo Falls on the road.
There was a bridge nearby.
There is no parking lot, so if you park your car at the end of the road and walk towards the back, you will come to a large field.
From there, there are many parts that are a little difficult to walk on, so please wear comfortable shoes.
I could see all the way to the bottom of the river and there were fish swimming around.
The first waterfall was captivated by its beautiful emerald green basin and the gorgeous flowing waterfall.
On the way to the second waterfall, I saw a rope stretched out so I could get down near the first waterfall, so I decided to go down.
Descending is dangerous, so it's best to be confident in your legs and hips.
As you go up the slope, you will see the second waterfall.
You can see the gorgeous flow and the beauty of the basin of the waterfall.
The second waterfall can be seen from above by climbing a small metal staircase.
I think it's a secret hidden gem.
There are no toilets.

If you go north on Prefectural Route 784, there will be signposts everywhere, so you won't get lost. Immediately after crossing the small bridge, turn left and go from the paved road to the unpaved forest road for about 50m. There is a parking lot that can accommodate 10 cars, and a promenade continues in the back. It's not that far to the waterfall, but you'll need to wear at least sneakers because you'll have to climb over a cliff just before. Saijobo Falls is an elegant waterfall with a wide basin, but unfortunately the viewing points are limited so you can only view it from one direction. If you have equipment such as waders, you may be able to stand in front. The promenade continued to the back, so when I continued on, I was surprised to see a splendid straight waterfall, and a few small but beautiful waterfalls here and there. And, for some reason, I was still surprised when I got out on the paved road. Apparently it can be accessed from upstream as well.

reviews.text: As you walk along the river from Mizuki Shrine to Takino Daimyojin, you will see Togeishi Falls in front of you. Both the height and the amount of water are quite impressive. There are many benches facing the waterfall, and in the summer it's nice to be bathed in negative ions.

This is a nice place that I happened to find while cycling.
It's a place where you can spend a relaxing time with few visitors, probably because it's in the mountains.

If you go north on Ken 28 from Takami, you will come to an intersection with Ken 31. Go left towards Ken 31, cross the bridge, and immediately turn right. There is a waterfall sign on the bridge railing. There is also a sign in front of Hakuba Temple, so you won't get lost. The parking lot at the temple is small, but it can accommodate about 2 cars. The waterfall can be reached in about 5 minutes by walking along the river from the right towards the main hall of Hakuba Temple. It is a flat worship road. There were huge trees in the surrounding area, and there was a sacred atmosphere.
2020.06 Although the waterfall is in an inconspicuous place, it was a soothing place with a very atmospheric approach path and huge cedar trees. 👍👍👍

It was in a place that was hard to find as I passed by it once. The navigation guided me to the road behind the waterfall (´+ω+｀) The road was narrow on one side, so I felt like I would cry if I saw an oncoming car. The parking lot also has 3.4 spaces. Since there is no line drawn, the amount may decrease depending on how you stop it. There were stairs to get into the river, so if you feel like going into the water, you might be able to see it up close. It can be difficult to drive when there are so many people, but it was a beautiful place.

reviews.text: 2022.8 We took the stream route, which took 550 minutes from the end of the forest road, including taking pictures of waterfalls and taking long breaks along the way, and the total travel time alone was 240 minutes. It was a 150 minute walk down the mountain on the Akotaki path. For the Sawa route, it is essential to be accompanied by someone who has the skills and has visited the area before. If you don't, you can simply climb up the Ako Falls path and go down the scree in front of the falls. The Ako Falls road is quite different from the route on the Geographical Survey Institute map. There are many sections with clear paths and tapes, but the more open the area is, the wider the gaps between the tapes, and there are tapes and tracks outside the route, so it's normal for inexperienced hikers to get lost. Although the amount of water was small, the beautiful rock walls and open space in front of the waterfall were wonderful. However, considering the time and route it took, it is a little strange. Forest roads along the Kamitago River from the national highway are often closed. Once the pavement was finished, there was a rough section all the way to the end, so I think it's better to stop while there's still pavement, just past Gyojin Falls.
This is where a B29 bomber crashed after the Osaka air raid. The engine is on display at the Tenkawa Village Museum
Perhaps due to the long rains, there was a lot of water, and it was more beautiful than I expected.

I read the instructions and it seems like it won't work in strong winds.
Unfortunately, there was no advance notice and I asked at the time of arrival.

There are no serving plates, so you will need to bring your own.

Purchase ingredients at Lopiya on the first floor.
You can easily have a BBQ.

It was cool and comfortable
I encountered a fistfight between a store employee and a customer.

Fighting...

I think the problem is that there is no one in charge who can handle complaints.

It's a comfortable and good facility for BBQ.
We hope that improvements will be made so that you can spend your time safely and securely.

I use it often.
The staff are always kind and helpful, so you can have a great time! If you separate your garbage, we will collect it for you, so it's easy!
Also, since the drinks at Lopia in Minara are not cold, I think it would be a good idea to use the all-you-can-drink menu on the beach. (All participating members had to order the all-you-can-drink option.) There are also dance shows on Saturdays and Sundays, so it's recommended! When we used it in the summer, there was a children's pool and they sold shaved ice, so the kids were very happy! I still want to use it!

・Leave the garbage as is.

・Comes with disposable chopsticks, plate, and towel
・With aluminum plate for fried noodles
・300 yen discount per person for purchases of 2,000 yen or more at Ropia
・You can also rent a cooler box for 600 yen (contains 2 bags of rock ice)

Even though it was raining, we were able to have a cool and comfortable BBQ and it was great!

It didn't have much of a beach feel, but I enjoyed the BBQ.
We recommend using the premium seats as they are more relaxing.
It was also nice to be able to easily purchase ingredients at Lopia in the same building and additional plates at Seria.
The staff at the store are kind, but you may have to wait because there aren't enough people.

To be honest, it's a terrible place and I don't want to go there again.
First of all, the sand on the beach is probably much better than the sandbox at the kindergarten. It's not a beach at all. The BBQ was still fun, but there was more to it than that.
First, I made a reservation for the afternoon session. Initially, we were told to come with about 6 people, but we managed to make a reservation for 4 people. I remember being very happy at that time. When I bought the ingredients and went to the BBQ, I had to call someone at the reception desk and wait, but no one came, and I ended up waiting for about 18 minutes. The BBQ started with some hesitation, but it went surprisingly smoothly. (There are no explanations about BBQ procedures or equipment, so it may be unfriendly for beginners.)As I gradually started using it, I almost ran out of the plates and chopsticks that were provided at the beginning, so I went to get some more. I decided to do it. (By the way, I confirmed over the phone that I could get extra paper plates and disposable chopsticks.) Then a young woman came (she was sitting there playing a game) and I asked her if I wanted extra plates. You'll need extra money,'' I was told. I haven't heard of that. Even though I said what I said on the phone, they didn't listen to me at all. In the end, even though I was originally told to clean up from 8:30, I finished eating at around 8:00, and while I was putting together the garbage, I started cleaning up the stove while I was talking, ``I have some leftover marshmallows, how about roasting them?'' It was. I have been to many places where you can have BBQ, but this is my first time doing something like this. I couldn't make a sound because I was more surprised than angry. Last but not least, the price here is 1200 yen per person. It may seem cheap at first glance, but it costs 4,800 yen for 4 people and 7,200 yen for 6 people. So, in addition to the stove and binchotan charcoal, I was only given paper plates, scissors, and tongs. This is not cheap at all. You can also rent hammocks and cooler boxes for an additional fee, but I don't use the cooler boxes much, and the hammocks aren't that good at all. If there are people who still want to go after seeing this, I won't stop them, but in this case, it would be much better to go to another BBQ place or have a BBQ at home on your own.
This is a very long post, but thank you for reading to the end. Please be careful not to make the same mistake as me.

*The above documents are personal opinions only.

reviews.text: Went for fireworks on 4th of July at night. It was fun. Very big area.

Very fun place for many outdoor activities,  we were focused on walking. It turns out that the trail around the lake joins up with the Bruce Freeman Trail which runs through several towns. Very lovely place,  lovingly tended , very clean bathrooms, free parking,  and this inviting park is appropriate for all ages.

This park has a lot to offer with a small beach, playground area, a trail that loops around the lake, a volleyball court, and an outdoor performance space. The only downsides were I noticed a fair amount of litter and part of the trail is near a lumberyard.

Great ground and a very lively atmosphere. We were playing cricket but there were several volleyball courts and the ground was filled with people. There are a few small trails and a pond .There is also a snack shop in the parking lot. Parking is abundantly available for free.

A very clean, well organized little park with swimming, walking, basketball and volleyball. A great place to take the whole family to enjoy the outdoors. There are covered picnic tables and ample shade, as well as open areas to enjoy the sun. They even have staffed concession centers, rentals, bathrooms and port-a-potties if needed!

A gigantic keyhole-shaped tumulus with a total length of 219m that belongs to the Sakitanami tomb group, one of the largest in Japan. It has been designated by the Imperial Household Agency as the mausoleum of Emperor Nintoku and Empress Iwafunenohime.
There is a water pond nearby, and the surrounding area has been designated as a special historical preservation district, so the environment and scenery around the tomb are wonderful, and it is a very relaxing space.
There are 5 ancient tombs over 200m in length that belong to the Sakidan-Ryu tomb group, and the Heijo Palace ruins are all within walking distance if you make the effort, so I recommend that you visit them at the same time! I visited on November 2, 2023.
Nara Prefecture has many ancient tombs, so if you unravel them one by one, you can learn a lot about their history.

It is said to be the mausoleum of Emperor Nintoku's Iwanohime no Mikoto, but the actual person buried here is unknown.
She was the daughter of the Katsuragi clan, a powerful family, and even Emperor Nintoku had no respect for the Empress.
In other words, without the power of the Katsuragi clan, the Emperor's position may have been in jeopardy.
Iwanohime is not buried in Katsuragi, her parents' home, but in this mecca of ancient tombs.

The mausoleum of Iwanohime, the 16th Emperor Nintoku Empress. She is described in the Chronicles as a very jealous empress. She was furious that her husband, Emperor Nintoku, had placed Princess Hatta in the Imperial Palace while he was away, so she moved to Tsutsujo Palace in Yamashiro, where she died. The tomb is not laid to rest next to her husband, Nintoku, but next to Princess Hatta.
Pleasant view.
Beautiful!

It is a huge keyhole-shaped tumulus.
A kofun that cannot be overlooked in the Saki kofun group.
There is a path that you can walk around, and if you go around it slowly, you can get a sense of its size and shape.

A keyhole-shaped tumulus with a total length of 255 meters that belongs to the Saki Tanami tumulus group, one of the largest in Japan, and is the 13th largest tumulus in Japan.
There is a water moat surrounding the kofun that receives an abundant amount of water, and the reflection of the kofun in the water moat is very beautiful. Combined with the nearby Iwanohime Mausoleum, the water moat of the Konabe Tumulus, and Minakami Pond,
A considerable waterfront has been formed, and many water birds visit, making it a valuable space, making it a truly beautiful and relaxing space.
If you make the effort, you can also visit the huge tumulus of over 200 meters in length and the ruins of Heijo Palace, which belong to the Sakidan-Ren Tumulus, as they are all within walking distance.
I visited on November 2, 2023.

It is a beautiful keyhole-shaped tumulus.
Uwanabe Tumulus, Konabe Tumulus.
You can also see the constriction of the keyhole shape.
There are other ancient tombs nearby.

I rented a bicycle at Nara Station the day before and enjoyed early morning cycling🚲
It is also close to the Heijo Palace ruins, so sightseeing by bicycle is recommended. Unlike Kyoto, each sightseeing spot in Nara is large and feels far apart from each other, so cycling is very convenient. Of course, you can also enjoy exploring by bus, taxi, or on foot.

As a foreigner it was the most useless place on the map. There are very few exhibits. The museum has 2 floors but only on the first floor you can take photos so basically you can take photos of two drums and that’s all. There was a banner proclaiming it as "Japan's Strongest Castle," which really piqued my interest, so I eagerly walked towards it. Since it had rained the previous day, the path was muddy, and it took about an hour to reach the top. Although I couldn't enjoy the view because it was covered in mist, I still had a great time.

There is no castle left, but the walls are well preserved, the viel from the top is breathtaking.
It is very easy to see, why this place was chosen for a castle back in the day. It would have beem very easily defendable.
All around the walls you can see the old roof tiles of the castle.

reviews.text: Great place. Free entry for foriegners with a show of passport and you get a free booklet with english explanations and four pull out postcards. The exhibits are amazingly interesting and I was absolutely enthralled. I highly reccomend!

Really nice museum describing a period of Japanese history that is often less discussed. I learned a lot about early Japanese history and culture. Highly recommend for those interested in history and archeology.

Amazing museum. Highly recommended if you're into history and archeology. Close to Kashihara Jingu and the Kofun of Emperor Jimmu. The museum covers the history of the area from the Paleolithic to the late Nara periods, and has a lot of amazing artifacts, dioramas and displays. Most displays are in Japanese but there is an English guidebook available.

Admission is 800 yen but if you're a foreigner you can get in for free if you show your passport.
Great collection. Free for foreigners if they show their passports.

reviews.text: Has a bunch of cool stuff, but not as much as the main museum and it repeats a lot of the same info. Fantastic showcasing of real digs though, which you can walk around via an elevated platform.

Free parking and free admission.
There are building models and excavated pillars, but I think what you should see is the real remains.
Both Fujiwara-kyo and Asuka-kyo were buried after being excavated, and only reproduction models can be seen, but even though they are ruins, the real buildings are deeply moving.

Personally, I have always been curious about where they got the soil to bury all of Heijo-kyo and how they buried it.

Speaking of sightseeing in Nara, it's the area around Nara Park. This is a must-visit spot after playing with deer. Admission and parking are free. However, if you go out from the exhibition hall and explore from Tai Chi Gate to the ruins of the past, it is quite a sight to see.
There are many things that feel old, such as wooden tablets and plaster from the past, but I was impressed by the solidity and luxury of the tiles.
Although we visited in the hot weather, we would like to thank the volunteers for their consideration.
Unlike the Suzakumon side, there are fewer people here, but there are more exhibits, so we recommend visiting here before walking around Heijo-kyo. Access to the Saki Kofun Group is also good.

Visited on February 17, 2024.
free entrance.

The north ridge at the entrance is about the second Daigokuden and the dairi. In the middle building, artifacts excavated from the government office are displayed. You can see the bricks from that time here.
In the south building, you can see the remains of a wall and its restoration.
The 塼 used in Heijokyo disappeared from Japanese history at some point, and it seems that the next appearance will be in the Meiji period.

I've heard that Heiankyo in Kyoto lasted for 1200 years because the entire town was washed away by occasional floods.

This is where the capital was located 1300 years ago (694~710). Buildings such as Tegoku-den and Chodo-in were built within an area of ​​about 1 km square, and this was the place where national ceremonies and politics were held.
Of course, it appears that the Emperor's residence, the Imperial Palace, was also built there.

There is a reference room on the second floor of JA next door. The building from that time has been recreated, and the lights are on so you can enjoy the atmosphere.

data.formatted_address: 233-1 Sakate, Tawaramoto, Shiki District, Nara 636-0247, Japan
data.name: Karako Kagi Archeological Museum

reviews.text: Very interesting, nice facility and the library is great!

Indoor museums are great when it's hot outside.
Although the information said that admission was free, I paid 200 yen for the general public to see it.
You can learn about the lifestyle and culture of people during the Yayoi period, about 2,000 years ago. As I was looking at it intently, the elderly guide inside the museum told me in detail, ``This horse-shaped clay was unearthed when XX Hospital was being built.'' ﾉ(´∀｀*) Arigato!! ︎
It can be seen that since ancient times, the Japanese people, who were good with their hands, had made various tools themselves and used them skillfully.
The admission fee of 200 yen is quite cheap.

This is a museum of relaxation.
The building is extremely splendid. It is located within the Tawaramoto Aogaki Lifelong Learning Center, but since the center includes a library, community center, and multipurpose hall, the exhibition space as a museum is just a small part of the magnificent building. On display are artifacts excavated from the nearby Kagi Ruins, including many painted pottery that provide clues to life at the time. There is no doubt that it is a valuable archaeological material that has been designated as a national important cultural property, but all of the drawings are crude and crude, and could be compared to the scribbles of a preschooler. If a person's face looks like a distorted grounded electrical outlet, and there is a mark on the lower abdomen of the horizontal line of Θ rotated 90 degrees, then the person is female. The pottery and figurines of the Jomon period have a high level of artistry even if they are not elaborate, so it is hard to wonder what could have gone wrong.
However, the charm of the Karako and Kagi Archaeological Museum is the sense of solitude that is created by the fact that the objects are displayed in such a serious manner without attracting attention to the graffiti. It's like sipping shochu while licking miso that has been toasted in a toaster oven without any snacks, and even if it doesn't look delicious, it's still enjoyable as long as it's Donbei.
Although it's a bit disappointing that we can't get a feel for the changes over time in the 700-year-old village ruins, which are said to be a characteristic of the Kagi ruins in the ancient times, along with the large amount of painted pottery, the exhibits are satisfying.

This is a recommended facility!
Since it is attached to the town's library and lifelong learning center, I didn't have high expectations when I visited, but it is a well-established facility with many excavated artifacts designated as important cultural properties on display. It's very clean and the exhibits are easy to understand, making it the perfect facility to study Yayoi's Yamato.
You can feel Tawaramoto Town's deep knowledge of ancient history, and you can see the ingenuity of the ancient people's lives and feel the breath of life.
We also had a volunteer guide who provided detailed explanations and talked about important points about ancient history research, which was a great learning experience.
In addition, it will be easier to understand the contents if you go to the ruins park before going to the museum.
Although the parking lot is shared with other centers, it is large and can be used without worry.
There is also a cafeteria inside the center, where we had lunch for ¥800.

It's a wonderful facility!
Anyone interested in ancient Japanese history should definitely visit this place.
About 1km north, you can see authentic pottery and other items excavated from the Ara Karakogi Ruins.
There are also jade magatama beads on display that shine beautifully and mysteriously against the greenery.
We highly recommend that you stop by this museum first rather than going directly to the Tanggukey ruins.
By looking here first, you can know where to see and what the highlights are before you visit the place.

There is much to learn from the numerous explanatory exhibits, including the topographical features of the Karakogi ruins and their positional relationship with the Makimuka ruins, the differences in time between the Karakogi ruins and the Makimuka ruins, the meanings of the Hatsuse River and the Terakawa, and the flow routes. I realized various things such as why there are straight sections.

There is a small entrance fee but I'm glad I visited

Located on the 2nd floor of Tawaramoto Town Lifelong Learning Center
There is also a cafe on the first floor.

The nearest station is Kintetsu Tawaramoto Station, but I think it takes about 25 minutes on foot.
Sightseeing station Isoki no Sato is located right outside the east exit of Tawaramoto Station.
There are rental bicycles here, so I think it would be a good idea to use them.
They also have electric cycles and lend you helmets.

If you take a leisurely bike ride along a paved country road 1km north of this museum, you will arrive at the Karakokey ruins that we just learned about.

It is now a beautifully maintained ruins park.

reviews.text: My favorite replicated stonework was Shumisen-seki stonework. Noted on my wonder-tips site.
