2024.5.10
As expected, this is a highly rated museum. Tourists first learn about Asuka's historical sites and history here. Then I think sightseeing is good 😊
Everyone from the receptionist to the lifeguards are kind ✌

Normally, the lifeguard would just stand there in a daze, but... ``Where's the water clock?'' ``Hi, I'll come this way.'' He quickly guides us around.
What a wonderful pamphlet, this will be a great souvenir.

These are replicas that look just like the real thing, but some of them are authentic and have been designated as important cultural properties. Everyone, please decide what to see on site depending on your time.

I focused on the water clock related to the Mizuochi ruins, which is the next planned site, and the stone human statues from the Ishigami ruins. You can see many ancient works of art in the beautiful garden outside.

Although the facility has quite a long history, it doesn't feel old-fashioned, perhaps because the exhibits are so impressive.
In addition to the exhibits in the museum, the restored or relocated stone structures on the premises are also quite impressive. As expected from "Asuka".

West of Todaiji Temple, west of Shosoin Temple, turn right north just before Emperor Shomu's territory and go straight up the slope. There is an explanatory text in front of the junior high school.

It seems like Hisashi Matsunaga built a castle and Nobunaga moved it there? Maybe it's because it's close to Todaiji Temple?

Was Shosoin to the northwest of Todaiji Temple, Emperor Shomu's tomb to the west, and Hisashi Matsunaga building a castle there?

Speaking of Nara's castles, it's Yamatokoriyama Castle, but is location important?

Nobbu, aren't you paying attention to Ieyasu when building Hamamatsu Castle? Castle enthusiast?

As you walk up the slope of a residential area, you will come to the gate of a junior high school. There is an information board about Tamon Castle next to the gate, but there is some construction going on, so maybe a slightly larger information board will be built. There are castle ruins inside the junior high school, but there is no way to go inside, and of course there is no parking lot. If you look back, you can see the Nara Basin clearly from the school gate. It is even more visible from the castle ruins where the school building is located, and you can really feel that it is a castle ruin. If you go back a little and take a detour, you can see the junior high school on the top of the cliff and see the cut marks.

Photographed in May 2021.

Castle ruins famous for the Sengoku era military commander Hisashi Matsunaga. Indeed, when you come here, you can get a good view of the Nara Basin, making it the perfect place to build a castle.

Until the Meiji period, Japanese people had no interest in Japan's cultural heritage, so despite being an important castle ruin, it is now a junior high school.

If there was no junior high school here, the castle would have been restored and turned into a tourist attraction.

Interests vary depending on the era, and in that sense, I think it's a very interesting place.

Because it is located on the grounds of Wakakusa Junior High School, you cannot go inside.
I am torn between the responsibility of building a school on a historical ruin and security concerns.
However, I am grateful that there is an information board outside the gate.
(Sometimes there are ridiculously self-centered local governments within schools.)
If you walk around the entire area, you can also see the territory of the castle.
Is the area where the bridge spans Ohori Kiri? !

Ruins of the castle of Hisashi Matsunaga.
It is also the place where Nobunaga cut off Rangemachi.
Beautiful garden. Free entry
Classical Japanese garden. Volunteers and securities are very helpful. I forgot my  cell phone here, but they tried hard to help me find it. Very welcome atmosphere, highly recommended.

Passing through the entrance and beyond the board fence, a wonderful space spreads out. Inside the garden, which measures 100m from north to south and 80m from east to west, a complex-shaped pond spreads out in the center and you can take a walk around it.
There is a stylish corner tower in the southeast corner, an elegant ancient building connected by a flat bridge in the middle, and at the end of the bridge there is a gabled building with an atrium that has been restored in imitation of the Horyuji restaurant.There is a bench here, and the wind blows through. It feels good, the garden spreads out in front of you, and you can take a break and enjoy the atmosphere. There are not many tourists, and this garden is free, so I recommend it.

It's a beautiful and lovely garden. The scenery of the pond is charming.

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-12-2 Shimomaki, Kammaki, Kitakatsuragi District, Nara 639-0205, Japan
data.name: Ruin of Kataoka castle

reviews.text:
If you drive a regular car, you'll end up on a narrow road that would scrape against the wall of a private house, but it will come to a dead end. It's on an unpaved farm road. I was able to make a U-turn at a vacant lot along the way, but there was no place to stop and the road was narrow, so it would be safer to head on foot if possible.
There is an information board at the dead end, giving you a good view. The main castle's hill and dry moat will appear in front of you. However, it's private land, so it's best not to wander around too much.

The remains of a huge dry moat are farmland, and earthworks remain on three walls.

It is believed that the main enclosure and the band ring around the main enclosure date back to the Kataoka period, while Ohorikiri, other Horikiri, and other enclosures were probably built during the Matsunaga Hisashi era.
It is a method that would not appear until the end of the Sengoku period, such as the linear combination of horikiri and earthworks, and large horikiri.
Hisashi Matsunaga is said to be a ``castle master'' who built the castle towers of Shigiyama Castle and Tamonyama Castle, and after becoming a vassal of Oda Nobunaga, he exchanged the Oda side's castle construction techniques and implemented even more complex Kuruwa arrangements. It is thought.
It is believed that Kataoka Castle was able to carry out a variety of operations by renovating the Ohorikiri and defending the main keep and south kuruwa as an area.

I took a stroll around Yamato Kataoka Castle during my morning walk😊 It was quiet and perfect for a walk, but as an outsider I was nervous because the signboard had words like "Private Land" and "Chikan"😅

In the area where the main keep was, there are signs explaining Kataoka Castle and the cultural assets nearby. The area that appears to be the main enclosure is densely populated and you cannot enter the grounds...perhaps it is private land? ? ?

Also, there is a private house nearby and if I was wandering around, I would be reported as a suspicious person, so I cut it short. It’s a shame 😓

It is not recommended to go to the main enclosure by car.
I think it's best to park your car somewhere and then walk.
It can also be a light exercise 😃
There are no toilets, so please be careful! ️

This is the place where the brothers Hosokawa Tadaoki and Okimoto achieved military exploits during their young samurai days.
During the Matsunaga attack, the castle, which was a branch castle of Shigisan Castle and was protected by approximately 1,000 Matsunaga troops led by Ebina Tomokiyo and Mori Masatomo, was attacked by approximately 5,000 Oda troops led by Akechi Mitsuhide, Hosokawa Fujitaka, Tsutsui Junkei, and others. Both the older brother, Tadaoki, who had recently fought for the first time, and the younger brother, Okimoto, who had fought in this battle for the first time, were the most accomplished with the spear.
Nobunaga recognized this and gave a handwritten letter of appreciation to both of them.

It used to be that you couldn't go inside because it was private land, but now you can go into the main building.

The main structure and the curved ring below it were easy to understand.

I wanted to go around other than the main castle, but I couldn't because it was on private land and looked like it was covered in bushes ^^;

The main castle is overgrown with vegetation and there is no view, but if you go down to the Katsushimo River you can clearly see Mt. Shigi and understand the relative position of the castle and Shigisan Castle.

The road to the castle ruins is only wide enough for a light truck to pass, and there is no parking space, so we do not recommend driving.
It is difficult to reach by car, so we recommend walking. I went to take a photo to get the Gofun seal of Kamimaki Town.

data.formatted_address: Amar Chand Mansion, Madame Cama Rd, Dr Ambedkar Statue Chowk Area, Colaba, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400001, India
data.name: Nara Thai, Colaba

reviews.text: We visited with 6 y old kid and 6 month old baby and staff managed to provide us a quiet corner where we could enjoy food without any disturbance.  Service was excellent and caring for the guests.  Food was awesome. Those who love Thai food would be must to try this place. Price is higherside and food quantity  is less but taste is authentic

We'd made a reservation on Dineout, but the restaurant couldn't locate it. It was a Saturday evening and the place was packed, anyhow they seated us pretty quickly.

Once they gave us the menus, two different people told us about Nara's food philosophy. What was funny was that both of them could only remember the names of the same 4 out of the 5 flavours that their cuisine is about.

We ordered,
1. Mango Salad
2. Stir fried water chestnuts & cashew nuts
3. Chicken wrapped in Pandan leaves
4. Mango sticky rice
The food's delicious, portions are very generous for 2 people and the service is fantastic. Our salad was served pretty quickly.

The only reason I wouldn't want to go back here on a weekend or in the evenings is because the place is designed in such a way that sound/noise isn't absorbed at all, I don't think the hard floor and mirrored wall help. The din was overwhelming and I couldn't hear a thing my partner was saying, it was worse than eating in an Udupi. Even the lighting was a big put off as there was just one spot light pointed at the centre of our table and the rest was dark. So we had to lean in to read the menu and were practically eating in the dark because once the food was served, it sat on the plate in the dark. It's a pity because the food & service is excellent.

My first visit and loved the taste of every dish. The service was extraordinary. The food was spicy but super tasty. We would visit this restaurant again soon. The restaurant is also very spacious and loved the seating.

Food was extremely delicious especially the appetizers. The staff was very courteous and polite. The washroom is clean. Mango sticky rice was not available though. Visited second time Yoder and was able to order delicious mango sticky rice as well.

My recent experience at Nara Thai was exceptional. The pepper garlic crab was delicious and so was the padseu. The Thai phrata is also delicious. The service was good and friendly and the restaurant is calm and peaceful( this is on a Sunday).

reviews.text: End of station in visiting tourist attractions in Nara. Walking distance to some of the tourist area. Just go straight after leaving the train and go up the stairs and walk straigth for about 10-15 minutes  to Nara Park. Staff are helpful to the tourist especially what train to ride when going home if you don't know which train to board that will pass to your desired specific station.

Of the two Nara stations, I recommend the Kintetsu Nara Station. It is closest to Nara Park.  You could take a direct line from Osaka Namba station to Nara.  From Nara, you can also take an Express train to Kyoto.

Train stop for Kintetsu-Nara Aoniyoshi & Hinotori Scenic train. Sight seeing limited express train connecting Osaka, Nara and Kyoto. Refurbished train of the  late 1960-1970s, luxuries modern with spacious seating arrangement for quiet relax at affordable rates (~1740JPY)

Really convenient station located near walkung distance to all the main sites of Nara (10-15min). Kintetsu also has special trains scheduled during portions of the day so if your schedule matches, make sure to try and experience some of them!

Nice station and very helpfull staff. Usually crowded and you can many tourist groups with guide travelling toward Nara park and Buddha temple. Plenty of good restaurants outside the station. I love the "welcome Nara" board!!!

Nara is a place worth visiting, without further explaining!
Check this special 360 video walking around Nara City area, including JR station, nearby streets, down to Tontaji and Nara garden!
Experience yourself!
https://youtu.be/twFnFSmh5mA

There is no problem at the station, but I would like to complain about the toilet downstairs. When I first came to Nara, I went there once and found a squatting pit filled with excrement! I went there for the second time today, and one of the toilets inside was even more disgusting 🤮, with excrement all over the floor!
Great station close to the main parts of Nara. Ready to walk to and from Nara Park. If you don't want to walk you can take a bus or taxi.

JR Nara Station is one of two main railway stations serving the city of Nara, the other being Kintetsu Nara Station. If you have a Japan Rail Pass then this is the station that you will use when visiting Nara. Though JR Nara Station is not as centrally located as Kintetsu Nara Station, it is still within walking distance of the city’s main attractions and is also very well connected with bus links and taxis.

Fortunately, JR Nara Station is quite compact and easy to navigate, with just five platforms and one set of ticket gates. Despite its small size, the station has plenty of useful amenities and there is also a lot of information available to help you find your way around. In this article we will explain the general layout of the station and introduce some of the useful facilities that are available.

This is one of the iconic viewpoints representing Osaka.
It is highly recommended as one of the tourist spots to visit in Osaka. Located within the Ikoma Sanjo Amusement Park.
Nice view

Located within Ikoma Sanjo Amusement Park.
Admission to the amusement park is free, so
I went for the observation deck.
It's a great panoramic view of Osaka.
Both day and night are amazing.
The Yodogawa Fireworks Festival is small but far away.
You can see.

Observation deck at Ikoma Sanjo Amusement Park

Admission to Yamagami Amusement Park is free of charge.
There is a fee to ride the play equipment.

There is also a one-day free pass, so please take advantage of it.

The observation deck is located right at the entrance of the park by stairs or gondola from the parking lot, and if you look to the west you can see Osaka city, and if you look to the east you can see the Nara Plain.

In the evening, you can see the orange sea as the setting sun reflects on the sea.

If you look closely in the photo, you can also see Harukas.

The best place to see the panoramic view of Osaka (relatively easily). There is no reason to go to Abeno Harukas. There is a separate Ikoma Mountain observatory (800m beyond the transmission tower), but this one, close to the cable car station, is easy to access. The trees and telephone poles are a bit obscured, but you can see it really well if you ride the ride right next to it. Outside of winter, the cable car stops early, so it may be difficult to see the night view.

Nice view point and easy to access, The both view of Osaka side and Nara side are available.

Park your car in the gravel parking lot for climbers, which seems to have enough space for 20 cars, and head to the observation deck!

There is a short distance from the parking lot to the trailhead, and after passing through the landmark torii gate, the trail passes through a fairly steep residential area.
The trail continues to be quite steep for a while from the trailhead, and you'll experience a light baptism. Once you cross this point, the gradual climb continues. There was a lot of shade from the trees, so it was relatively cool to climb. The road is a wide, paved road, and there are no cars or motorcycles.
It will take you 30 minutes to reach the observation deck.
I went on a weekday evening, and it was pretty empty. Or rather, it's rattling.
The observation deck is a wooden deck and is designed to surround the Nara and Osaka sides. Each location has one free telescope.
Fortunately, there are also toilets and vending machines. The toilet building is old, but the equipment is new and has a washlet. There is no hand soap in the washroom...
It was quite hazy today so I wasn't expecting much, but I still managed to barely see the Akashi Kaikyo Bridge! Harukas also appeared floating in the haze and looked fantastic.

data.name: The Rooftop of Nara Prefecture Office

reviews.text: Nice view
Very nice views of the city

A little-known spot where anyone can enjoy the scenery of Nara for free.
There are no buildings taller than the prefectural office in the surrounding area, so the view is spectacular.

However, the available hours are limited, so please check before visiting.
You can also enter on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays.
If you enter from the main entrance of the prefectural office, there will be an elevator hall and a guide sign, so you won't get lost.
There are also several benches
However, eating such as boxed lunches is prohibited.
There is a paper cup vending machine

If you enter the prefectural office and take the elevator to the roof, you will find a free observation deck.
You can enjoy a 360-degree view of Nara City and cultural properties from above.
You can also use the telescope for free.
You can have a great experience in a hidden gem.

360° panorama! It's a rooftop plaza of the Nara Prefectural Office where you can see Mt. Wakakusa, Mt. Ikoma, and Nara City.
It is free to use, and the rooftop is open even on weekends and holidays when the prefectural office is closed.
Sentokun will meet you at the entrance.
Enter and take the elevator on the left to the roof.
If the time and weather are good, you can also see a beautiful sunset.
The observatory and the telescope are also free!
There are benches scattered about, so you can enjoy the scenery of Nara slowly.
There is also an observation deck above the rooftop plaza, but it was closed on this day.
There was also a parent and fawn (*object)

Today, on December 30, 2023, I explored tranquil surroundings that would have been idyllic if the cherry trees weren't nearly bare, with only their branches visible. This place resembles a paradise, especially during spring and cherry blossom seasons, with deer adding to the serene ambiance. Unfortunately, around 90% of the area seems to be closed, long holidays in Japan starts Dec 28 - Jan 3.
A calm and serene pond in the middle of the Nara Park district! Really beautiful!
A tranquil area with cherry blossoms and deer to keep you company.
Gorgeous area

Being able to rent the ebikes was the highlight of our Nara trip.
The rooms were so unique and comfortable.
The hotel itself was gorgeous and well kept.
The staff were beyond helpful.

Beautiful hotel with a rich history. Staff was extremely nice and helpful. Dinner in the Japanese restaurant was  a unique and awesome experience. My Finance had a food allergy and they accommodated her needs. Definitely make sure you go to the bar  and enjoy the view.

Lives up to the reputation. Beautifully antique hotel meticulously up-kept to carry its history gracefully. The bar is stunning and brings you back in time. $8 taxi from train station and you are walking distance to the temples and shrines.

Currently, I am staying in Nara Hotel! Very historical hotel and really traditional. Classic, beautiful, and gorgeous. Staff are truly working hard, kind, and nice. The room is extremely big but quiet. The room has an amazing balcony with awesome views. I can say that it is one of the topest hotels in Japan. Price is reasonable but very luxurious.
